verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:2
verses.text: In the Beginning God made the Heaven and the Earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:4
verses.text: It is right that any one beginning to narrate the formation of the world should begin with the good order which reigns in visible things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:5
verses.text: I am about to speak of the creation of heaven and earth, which was not spontaneous, as some have imagined, but drew its origin from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:6
verses.text: What ear is worthy to hear such a tale? How earnestly the soul should prepare itself to receive such high lessons! How pure it should be from carnal affections, how unclouded by worldly disquietudes, how active and ardent in its researches, how eager to find in its surroundings an idea of God which may be worthy of Him!  But before weighing the justice of these remarks, before examining all the sense contained in these few words, let us see who addresses them to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:7
verses.text: Because, if the weakness of our intelligence does not allow us to penetrate the depth of the thoughts of the writer, yet we shall be involuntarily drawn to give faith to his words by the force of his authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:8
verses.text: Now it is Moses who has composed this history; Moses, who, when still at the breast, is described as exceeding fair; Moses, whom the daughter of Pharaoh adopted; who received from her a royal education, and who had for his teachers the wise men of Egypt; Moses, who disdained the pomp of royalty, and, to share the humble condition of his compatriots, preferred to be persecuted with the people of God rather than to enjoy the fleeting delights of sin; Moses, who received from nature such a love of justice that, even before the leadership of the people of God was committed to him, he was impelled, by a natural horror of evil, to pursue malefactors even to the point of punishing them by death; Moses, who, banished by those whose benefactor he had been, hastened to escape from the tumults of Egypt and took refuge in Ethiopia, living there far from former pursuits, and passing forty years in the contemplation of nature; Moses, finally, who, at the age of eighty, saw God, as far as it is possible for man to see Him; or rather as it had not previously been granted to man to see Him, according to the testimony of God Himself, "If there be a prophet among you, I the Lord will make myself known unto him in a vision, and will speak unto him in a dream.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:9
verses.text: My servant Moses is not so, who is faithful in all mine house, with him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently and not in dark speeches".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:10
verses.text: It is this man, whom God judged worthy to behold Him, face to face, like the angels, who imparts to us what he has learnt from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:11
verses.text: Let us listen then to these words of truth written without the help of the "enticing words of man's wisdom" by the dictation of the Holy Spirit; words destined to produce not the applause of those who hear them, but the salvation of those who are instructed by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:13
verses.text: "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:14
verses.text: I stop struck with admiration at this thought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:15
verses.text: What shall I first say? Where shall I begin my story? Shall I show forth the vanity of the Gentiles? Shall I exalt the truth of our faith? The philosophers of Greece have made much ado to explain nature, and not one of their systems has remained firm and unshaken, each being overturned by its successor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:16
verses.text: It is vain to refute them; they are sufficient in themselves to destroy one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:17
verses.text: Those who were too ignorant to rise to a knowledge of a God, could not allow that an intelligent cause presided at the birth of the Universe; a primary error that involved them in sad consequences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:18
verses.text: Some had recourse to material principles and attributed the origin of the Universe to the elements of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:19
verses.text: Others imagined that atoms, and indivisible bodies, molecules and ducts, form, by their union, the nature of the visible world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:20
verses.text: Atoms reuniting or separating, produce births and deaths and the most durable bodies only owe their consistency to the strength of their mutual adhesion: a true spider's web woven by these writers who give to heaven, to earth, and to sea so weak an origin and so little consistency! It is because they knew not how to say "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:21
verses.text: Deceived by their inherent atheism it appeared to them that nothing governed or ruled the universe, and that was all was given up to chance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:22
verses.text: To guard us against this error the writer on the creation, from the very first words, enlightens our understanding with the name of God; "In the beginning God created".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:23
verses.text: What a glorious order! He first establishes a beginning, so that it might not be supposed that the world never had a beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:24
verses.text: Then he adds "Created" to show that which was made was a very small part of the power of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:25
verses.text: In the same way that the potter, after having made with equal pains a great number of vessels, has not exhausted either his art or his talent; thus the Maker of the Universe, whose creative power, far from being bounded by one world, could extend to the infinite, needed only the impulse of His will to bring the immensities of the visible world into being.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:26
verses.text: If then the world has a beginning, and if it has been created, enquire who gave it this beginning, and who was the Creator: or rather, in the fear that human reasonings may make you wander from the truth, Moses has anticipated enquiry by engraving in our hearts, as a seal and a safeguard, the awful name of God: "In the beginning God created"—It is He, beneficent Nature, Goodness without measure, a worthy object of love for all beings endowed with reason, the beauty the most to be desired, the origin of all that exists, the source of life, intellectual light, impenetrable wisdom, it is He who "in the beginning created heaven and earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:28
verses.text: Do not then imagine, O man! that the visible world is without a beginning; and because the celestial bodies move in a circular course, and it is difficult for our senses to define the point where the circle begins, do not believe that bodies impelled by a circular movement are, from their nature, without a beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:29
verses.text: Without doubt the circle (I mean the plane figure described by a single line) is beyond our perception, and it is impossible for us to find out where it begins or where it ends; but we ought not on this account to believe it to be without a beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:30
verses.text: Although we are not sensible of it, it really begins at some point where the draughtsman has begun to draw it at a certain radius from the centre.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:31
verses.text: Thus seeing that figures which move in a circle always return upon themselves, without for a single instant interrupting the regularity of their course, do not vainly imagine to yourselves that the world has neither beginning nor end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:32
verses.text: "For the fashion of this world passeth away" and "Heaven and earth shall pass away".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:33
verses.text: The dogmas of the end, and of the renewing of the world, are announced beforehand in these short words put at the head of the inspired history.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:34
verses.text: "In the beginning God made".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:35
verses.text: That which was begun in time is condemned to come to an end in time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:36
verses.text: If there has been a beginning do not doubt of the end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:37
verses.text: Of what use then are geometry—the calculations of arithmetic—the study of solids and far-famed astronomy, this laborious vanity, if those who pursue them imagine that this visible world is co-eternal with the Creator of all things, with God Himself; if they attribute to this limited world, which has a material body, the same glory as to the incomprehensible and invisible nature; if they cannot conceive that a whole, of which the parts are subject to corruption and change, must of necessity end by itself submitting to the fate of its parts? But they have become "vain in their imaginations and their foolish heart was darkened.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:38
verses.text: Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:39
verses.text: Some have affirmed that heaven co-exists with God from all eternity; others that it is God Himself without beginning or end, and the cause of the particular arrangement of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:41
verses.text: One day, doubtless, their terrible condemnation will be the greater for all this worldly wisdom, since, seeing so clearly into vain sciences, they have wilfully shut their eyes to the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:42
verses.text: These men who measure the distances of the stars and describe them, both those of the North, always shining brilliantly in our view, and those of the southern pole visible to the inhabitants of the South, but unknown to us; who divide the Northern zone and the circle of the Zodiac into an infinity of parts, who observe with exactitude the course of the stars, their fixed places, their declensions, their return and the time that each takes to make its revolution; these men, I say, have discovered all except one thing: the fact that God is the Creator of the universe, and the just Judge who rewards all the actions of life according to their merit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:43
verses.text: They have not known how to raise themselves to the idea of the consummation of all things, the consequence of the doctrine of judgment, and to see that the world must change if souls pass from this life to a new life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:44
verses.text: In reality, as the nature of the present life presents an affinity to this world, so in the future life our souls will enjoy a lot conformable to their new condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:45
verses.text: But they are so far from applying these truths, that they do but laugh when we announce to them the end of all things and the regeneration of the age.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:46
verses.text: Since the beginning naturally precedes that which is derived from it, the writer, of necessity, when speaking to us of things which had their origin in time, puts at the head of his narrative these words—"In the beginning God created".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:48
verses.text: It appears, indeed, that even before this world an order of things existed of which our mind can form an idea, but of which we can say nothing, because it is too lofty a subject for men who are but beginners and are still babes in knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:49
verses.text: The birth of the world was preceded by a condition of things suitable for the exercise of supernatural powers, outstripping the limits of time, eternal and infinite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:50
verses.text: The Creator and Demiurge of the universe perfected His works in it, spiritual light for the happiness of all who love the Lord, intellectual and invisible natures, all the orderly arrangement of pure intelligences who are beyond the reach of our mind and of whom we cannot even discover the names.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:51
verses.text: They fill the essence of this invisible world, as Paul teaches us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:52
verses.text: "For by him were all things created that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible whether they be thrones or dominions or principalities or powers" or virtues or hosts of angels or the dignities of archangels.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:53
verses.text: To this world at last it was necessary to add a new world, both a school and training place where the souls of men should be taught and a home for beings destined to be born and to die.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:54
verses.text: Thus was created, of a nature analogous to that of this world and the animals and plants which live thereon, the succession of time, for ever pressing on and passing away and never stopping in its course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:55
verses.text: Is not this the nature of time, where the past is no more, the future does not exist, and the present escapes before being recognised? And such also is the nature of the creature which lives in time,—condemned to grow or to perish without rest and without certain stability.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:56
verses.text: It is therefore fit that the bodies of animals and plants, obliged to follow a sort of current, and carried away by the motion which leads them to birth or to death, should live in the midst of surroundings whose nature is in accord with beings subject to change.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:57
verses.text: Thus the writer who wisely tells us of the birth of the Universe does not fail to put these words at the head of the narrative.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:58
verses.text: "In the beginning God created;" that is to say, in the beginning of time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:59
verses.text: Therefore, if he makes the world appear in the beginning, it is not a proof that its birth has preceded that of all other things that were made.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:60
verses.text: He only wishes to tell us that, after the invisible and intellectual world, the visible world, the world of the senses, began to exist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:61
verses.text: The first movement is called beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:62
verses.text: "To do right is the beginning of the good way".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:63
verses.text: Just actions are truly the first steps towards a happy life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:64
verses.text: Again, we call "beginning" the essential and first part from which a thing proceeds, such as the foundation of a house, the keel of a vessel; it is in this sense that it is said, "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom," that is to say that piety is, as it were, the groundwork and foundation of perfection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:65
verses.text: Art is also the beginning of the works of artists, the skill of Bezaleel began the adornment of the tabernacle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:66
verses.text: Often even the good which is the final cause is the beginning of actions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:67
verses.text: Thus the approbation of God is the beginning of almsgiving, and the end laid up for us in the promises the beginning of all virtuous efforts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:69
verses.text: Such being the different senses of the word beginning, see if we have not all the meanings here.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:70
verses.text: You may know the epoch when the formation of this world began, it, ascending into the past, you endeavour to discover the first day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:71
verses.text: You will thus find what was the first movement of time; then that the creation of the heavens and of the earth were like the foundation and the groundwork, and afterwards that an intelligent reason, as the word beginning indicates, presided in the order of visible things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:72
verses.text: You will finally discover that the world was not conceived by chance and without reason, but for an useful end and for the great advantage of all beings, since it is really the school where reasonable souls exercise themselves, the training ground where they learn to know God; since by the sight of visible and sensible things the mind is led, as by a hand, to the contemplation of invisible things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:73
verses.text: "For," as the Apostle says, "the invisible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:74
verses.text: Perhaps these words "In the beginning God created" signify the rapid and imperceptible moment of creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:75
verses.text: The beginning, in effect, is indivisible and instantaneous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:76
verses.text: The beginning of the road is not yet the road, and that of the house is not yet the house; so the beginning of time is not yet time and not even the least particle of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:77
verses.text: If some objector tell us that the beginning is a time, he ought then, as he knows well, to submit it to the division of time—a beginning, a middle and an end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:78
verses.text: Now it is ridiculous to imagine a beginning of a beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:79
verses.text: Further, if we divide the beginning into two, we make two instead of one, or rather make several, we really make an infinity, for all that which is divided is divisible to the infinite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:80
verses.text: Thus then, if it is said, "In the beginning God created," it is to teach us that at the will of God the world arose in less than an instant, and it is to convey this meaning more clearly that other interpreters have said: "God made summarily" that is to say all at once and in a moment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:81
verses.text: But enough concerning the beginning, if only to put a few points out of many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:83
verses.text: Among arts, some have in view production, some practice, others theory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:84
verses.text: The object of the last is the exercise of thought, that of the second, the motion of the body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:85
verses.text: Should it cease, all stops; nothing more is to be seen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:86
verses.text: Thus dancing and music have nothing behind; they have no object but themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:87
verses.text: In creative arts on the contrary the work lasts after the operation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:88
verses.text: Such is architecture—such are the arts which work in wood and brass and weaving, all those indeed which, even when the artisan has disappeared, serve to show an industrious intelligence and to cause the architect, the worker in brass or the weaver, to be admired on account of his work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:89
verses.text: Thus, then, to show that the world is a work of art displayed for the beholding of all people; to make them know Him who created it, Moses does not use another word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:90
verses.text: "In the beginning," he says "God created".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:91
verses.text: He does not say "God worked," "God formed," but "God created".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:92
verses.text: Among those who have imagined that the world co-existed with God from all eternity, many have denied that it was created by God, but say that it exists spontaneously, as the shadow of this power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:93
verses.text: God, they say, is the cause of it, but an involuntary cause, as the body is the cause of the shadow and the flame is the cause of the brightness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:94
verses.text: It is to correct this error that the prophet states, with so much precision, "In the beginning God created".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:95
verses.text: He did not make the thing itself the cause of its existence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:96
verses.text: Being good, He made it an useful work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:97
verses.text: Being wise, He made it everything that was most beautiful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:98
verses.text: Being powerful He made it very great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:99
verses.text: Moses almost shows us the finger of the supreme artisan taking possession of the substance of the universe, forming the different parts in one perfect accord, and making a harmonious symphony result from the whole.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:100
verses.text: "In the beginning God made heaven and earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:101
verses.text: By naming the two extremes, he suggests the substance of the whole world, according to heaven the privilege of seniority, and putting earth in the second rank.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:102
verses.text: All intermediate beings were created at the same time as the extremities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:103
verses.text: Thus, although there is no mention of the elements, fire, water and air, imagine that they were all compounded together, and you will find water, air and fire, in the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:104
verses.text: For fire leaps out from stones; iron which is dug from the earth produces under friction fire in plentiful measure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:105
verses.text: A marvellous fact! Fire shut up in bodies lurks there hidden without harming them, but no sooner is it released than it consumes that which has hitherto preserved it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:106
verses.text: The earth contains water, as diggers of wells teach us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:107
verses.text: It contains air too, as is shown by the vapours that it exhales under the sun's warmth when it is damp.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:108
verses.text: Now, as according to their nature, heaven occupies the higher and earth the lower position in space, (one sees, in fact, that all which is light ascends towards heaven, and heavy substances fall to the ground); as therefore height and depth are the points the most opposed to each other it is enough to mention the most distant parts to signify the inclusion of all which fills up intervening Space.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:109
verses.text: Do not ask, then, for an enumeration of all the elements; guess, from what Holy Scripture indicates, all that is passed over in silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:111
verses.text: "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:112
verses.text: If we were to wish to discover the essence of each of the beings which are offered for our contemplation, or come under our senses, we should be drawn away into long digressions, and the solution of the problem would require more words than I possess, to examine fully the matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:113
verses.text: To spend time on such points would not prove to be to the edification of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:114
verses.text: Upon the essence of the heavens we are contented with what Isaiah says, for, in simple language, he gives us sufficient idea of their nature, "The heaven was made like smoke," that is to say, He created a subtle substance, without solidity or density, from which to form the heavens.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:115
verses.text: As to the form of them we also content ourselves with the language of the same prophet, when praising God "that stretcheth out the heavens as a curtain and spreadeth them out as a tent to dwell in".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:116
verses.text: In the same way, as concerns the earth, let us resolve not to torment ourselves by trying to find out its essence, not to tire our reason by seeking for the substance which it conceals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:117
verses.text: Do not let us seek for any nature devoid of qualities by the conditions of its existence, but let us know that all the phenomena with which we see it clothed regard the conditions of its existence and complete its essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:118
verses.text: Try to take away by reason each of the qualities it possesses, and you will arrive at nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:119
verses.text: Take away black, cold, weight, density, the qualities which concern taste, in one word all these which we see in it, and the substance vanishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:120
verses.text: If I ask you to leave these vain questions, I will not expect you to try and find out the earth's point of support.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:121
verses.text: The mind would reel on beholding its reasonings losing themselves without end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:122
verses.text: Do you say that the earth reposes on a bed of air? How, then, can this soft substance, without consistency, resist the enormous weight which presses upon it? How is it that it does not slip away in all directions, to avoid the sinking weight, and to spread itself over the mass which overwhelms it? Do you suppose that water is the foundation of the earth? You will then always have to ask yourself how it is that so heavy and opaque a body does not pass through the water; how a mass of such a weight is held up by a nature weaker than itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:123
verses.text: Then you must seek a base for the waters, and you will be in much difficulty to say upon what the water itself rests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:125
verses.text: Do you suppose that a heavier body prevents the earth from falling into the abyss? Then you must consider that this support needs itself a support to prevent it from falling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:126
verses.text: Can we imagine one? Our reason again demands yet another support, and thus we shall fall into the infinite, always imagining a base for the base which we have already found.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:127
verses.text: And the further we advance in this reasoning the greater force we are obliged to give to this base, so that it may be able to support all the mass weighing upon it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:128
verses.text: Put then a limit to your thought, so that your curiosity in investigating the incomprehensible may not incur the reproaches of Job, and you be not asked by him, "Whereupon are the foundations thereof fastened?" If ever you hear in the Psalms, "I bear up the pillars of it;" see in these pillars the power which sustains it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:129
verses.text: Because what means this other passage, "He hath founded it upon the sea," if not that the water is spread all around the earth? How then can water, the fluid element which flows down every declivity, remain suspended without ever flowing? You do not reflect that the idea of the earth suspended by itself throws your reason into a like but even greater difficulty, since from its nature it is heavier.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:130
verses.text: But let us admit that the earth rests upon itself, or let us say that it rides the waters, we must still remain faithful to thought of true religion and recognise that all is sustained by the Creator's power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:131
verses.text: Let us then reply to ourselves, and let us reply to those who ask us upon what support this enormous mass rests, "In His hands are the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:132
verses.text: It is a doctrine as infallible for our own information as profitable for our hearers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:134
verses.text: There are inquirers into nature who with a great display of words give reasons for the immobility of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:135
verses.text: Placed, they say, in the middle of the universe and not being able to incline more to one side than the other because its centre is everywhere the same distance from the surface, it necessarily rests upon itself; since a weight which is everywhere equal cannot lean to either side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:136
verses.text: It is not, they go on, without reason or by chance that the earth occupies the centre of the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:137
verses.text: It is its natural and necessary position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:138
verses.text: As the celestial body occupies the higher extremity of space all heavy bodies, they argue, that we may suppose to have fallen from these high regions, will be carried from all directions to the centre, and the point towards which the parts are tending will evidently be the one to which the whole mass will be thrust together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:139
verses.text: If stones, wood, all terrestrial bodies, fall from above downwards, this must be the proper and natural place of the whole earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:140
verses.text: If, on the contrary, a light body is separated from the centre, it is evident that it will ascend towards the higher regions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:141
verses.text: Thus heavy bodies move from the top to the bottom, and following this reasoning, the bottom is none other than the centre of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:142
verses.text: Do not then be surprised that the world never falls: it occupies the centre of the universe, its natural place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:143
verses.text: By necessity it is obliged to remain in its place, unless a movement contrary to nature should displace it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:144
verses.text: If there is anything in this system which might appear probable to you, keep your admiration for the source of such perfect order, for the wisdom of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:145
verses.text: Grand phenomena do not strike us the less when we have discovered something of their wonderful mechanism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:146
verses.text: Is it otherwise here? At all events let us prefer the simplicity of faith to the demonstrations of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:148
verses.text: We might say the same thing of the heavens.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:149
verses.text: With what a noise of words the sages of this world have discussed their nature! Some have said that heaven is composed of four elements as being tangible and visible, and is made up of earth on account of its power of resistance, with fire because it is striking to the eye, with air and water on account of the mixture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:150
verses.text: Others have rejected this system as improbable, and introduced into the world, to form the heavens, a fifth element after their own fashioning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:151
verses.text: There exists, they say, an aethereal body which is neither fire, air, earth, nor water, nor in one word any simple body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:152
verses.text: These simple bodies have their own natural motion in a straight line, light bodies upwards and heavy bodies downwards; now this motion upwards and downwards is not the same as circular motion; there is the greatest possible difference between straight and circular motion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:153
verses.text: It therefore follows that bodies whose motion is so various must vary also in their essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:154
verses.text: But, it is not even possible to suppose that the heavens should be formed of primitive bodies which we call elements, because the reunion of contrary forces could not produce an even and spontaneous motion, when each of the simple bodies is receiving a different impulse from nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:155
verses.text: Thus it is a labour to maintain composite bodies in continual movement, because it is impossible to put even a single one of their movements in accord and harmony with all those that are in discord; since what is proper to the light particle, is in warfare with that of a heavier one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:156
verses.text: If we attempt to rise we are stopped by the weight of the terrestrial element; if we throw ourselves down we violate the igneous part of our being in dragging it down contrary to its nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:157
verses.text: Now this struggle of the elements effects their dissolution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:158
verses.text: A body to which violence is done and which is placed in opposition to nature, after a short but energetic resistance, is soon dissolved into as many parts as it had elements, each of the constituent parts returning to its natural place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:159
verses.text: It is the force of these reasons, say the inventors of the fifth kind of body for the genesis of heaven and the stars, which constrained them to reject the system of their predecessors and to have recourse to their own hypothesis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:160
verses.text: But yet another fine speaker arises and disperses and destroys this theory to give predominance to an idea of his own invention.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:161
verses.text: Do not let us undertake to follow them for fear of falling into like frivolities; let them refute each other, and, without disquieting ourselves about essence, let us say with Moses "God created the heavens and the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:162
verses.text: Let us glorify the supreme Artificer for all that was wisely and skillfully made; by the beauty of visible things let us raise ourselves to Him who is above all beauty; by the grandeur of bodies, sensible and limited in their nature, let us conceive of the infinite Being whose immensity and omnipotence surpass all the efforts of the imagination.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 1:163
verses.text: Because, although we ignore the nature of created things, the objects which on all sides attract our notice are so marvellous, that the most penetrating mind cannot attain to the knowledge of the least of the phenomena of the world, either to give a suitable explanation of it or to render due praise to the Creator, to Whom belong all glory, all honour and all power world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:2
verses.text: "The Earth was Invisible and Unfinished".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:4
verses.text: In the few words which have occupied us this morning we have found such a depth of thought that we despair of penetrating further.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:5
verses.text: If such is the fore court of the sanctuary, if the portico of the temple is so grand and magnificent, if the splendour of its beauty thus dazzles the eyes of the soul, what will be the holy of holies? Who will dare to try to gain access to the innermost shrine? Who will look into its secrets? To gaze into it is indeed forbidden us, and language is powerless to express what the mind conceives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:6
verses.text: However, since there are rewards, and most desirable ones, reserved by the just Judge for the intention alone of doing good, do not let us hesitate to continue our researches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:7
verses.text: Although we may not attain to the truth, if, with the help of the Spirit, we do not fall away from the meaning of Holy Scripture we shall not deserve to be rejected, and, with the help of grace, we shall contribute to the edification of the Church of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:8
verses.text: "The earth," says Holy Scripture, "was invisible and unfinished".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:9
verses.text: The heavens and the earth were created without distinction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:10
verses.text: How then is it that the heavens are perfect whilst the earth is still unformed and incomplete? In one word, what was the unfinished condition of the earth? And for what reason was it invisible? The fertility of the earth is its perfect finishing; growth of all kinds of plants, the upspringing of tall trees, both productive and sterile, flowers' sweet scents and fair colours, and all that which, a little later, at the voice of God came forth from the earth to beautify her, their universal Mother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:11
verses.text: As nothing of all this yet existed, Scripture is right in calling the earth "without form".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:12
verses.text: We could also say of the heavens that they were still imperfect and had not received their natural adornment, since at that time they did not shine with the glory of the sun and of the moon and were not crowned by the choirs of the stars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:13
verses.text: These bodies were not yet created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:14
verses.text: Thus you will not diverge from the truth in saying that the heavens also were "without form".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:15
verses.text: The earth was invisible for two reasons: it may be because man, the spectator, did not yet exist, or because being submerged under the waters which over-flowed the surface, it could not be seen, since the waters had not yet been gathered together into their own places, where God afterwards collected them, and gave them the name of seas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:16
verses.text: What is invisible? First of all that which our fleshly eye cannot perceive; our mind, for example; then that which, visible in its nature, is hidden by some body which conceals it, like iron in the depths of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:17
verses.text: It is in this sense, because it was hidden under the waters, that the earth was still invisible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:18
verses.text: However, as light did not yet exist, and as the earth lay in darkness, because of the obscurity of the air above it, it should not astonish us that for this reason Scripture calls it "invisible".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:20
verses.text: But the corrupters of the truth, who, incapable of submitting their reason to Holy Scripture, distort at will the meaning of the Holy Scriptures, pretend that these words mean matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:21
verses.text: For it is matter, they say, which from its nature is without form and invisible,—being by the conditions of its existence without quality and without form and figure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:22
verses.text: The Artificer submitting it to the working of His wisdom clothed it with a form, organized it, and thus gave being to the visible world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:23
verses.text: If matter is uncreated, it has a claim to the same honours as God, since it must be of equal rank with Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:24
verses.text: Is this not the summit of wickedness, that an extreme deformity, without quality, without form, shape, ugliness without configuration, to use their own expression, should enjoy the same prerogatives with Him, Who is wisdom, power and beauty itself, the Creator and the Demiurge of the universe? This is not all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:25
verses.text: If matter is so great as to be capable of being acted on by the whole wisdom of God, it would in a way raise its hypostasis to an equality with the inaccessible power of God, since it would be able to measure by itself all the extent of the divine intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:26
verses.text: If it is insufficient for the operations of God, then we fall into a more absurd blasphemy, since we condemn God for not being able, on account of the want of matter, to finish His own works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:27
verses.text: The poverty of human nature has deceived these reasoners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:28
verses.text: Each of our crafts is exercised upon some special matter—the art of the smith upon iron, that of the carpenter on wood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:29
verses.text: In all, there is the subject, the form and the work which results from the form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:30
verses.text: Matter is taken from without—art gives the form—and the work is composed at the same time of form and of matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:31
verses.text: Such is the idea that they make for themselves of the divine work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:32
verses.text: The form of the world is due to the wisdom of the supreme Artificer; matter came to the Creator from without; and thus the world results from a double origin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:33
verses.text: It has received from outside its matter and its essence, and from God its form and figure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:34
verses.text: They thus come to deny that the mighty God has presided at the formation of the universe, and pretend that He has only brought a crowning contribution to a common work, that He has only contributed some small portion to the genesis of beings: they are incapable from the debasement of their reasonings of raising their glances to the height of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:35
verses.text: Here below arts are subsequent to matter—introduced into life by the indispensable need of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:36
verses.text: Wool existed before weaving made it supply one of nature's imperfections.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:37
verses.text: Wood existed before carpentering took possession of it, and transformed it each day to supply new wants, and made us see all the advantages derived from it, giving the oar to the sailor, the winnowing fan to the labourer, the lance to the soldier.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:38
verses.text: But God, before all those things which now attract our notice existed, after casting about in His mind and determining to bring into being time which had no being, imagined the world such as it ought to be, and created matter in harmony with the form which He wished to give it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:39
verses.text: He assigned to the heavens the nature adapted for the heavens, and gave to the earth an essence in accordance with its form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:40
verses.text: He formed, as He wished, fire, air and water, and gave to each the essence which the object of its existence required.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:41
verses.text: Finally, He welded all the diverse parts of the universe by links of indissoluble attachment and established between them so perfect a fellowship and harmony that the most distant, in spite of their distance, appeared united in one universal sympathy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:42
verses.text: Let those men therefore renounce their fabulous imaginations, who, in spite of the weakness of their argument, pretend to measure a power as incomprehensible to man's reason as it is unutterable by man's voice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:44
verses.text: God created the heavens and the earth, but not only half;—He created all the heavens and all the earth, creating the essence with the form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:45
verses.text: For He is not an inventor of figures, but the Creator even of the essence of beings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:46
verses.text: Further let them tell us how the efficient power of God could deal with the passive nature of matter, the latter furnishing the matter without form, the former possessing the science of the form without matter, both being in need of each other; the Creator in order to display His art, matter in order to cease to be without form and to receive a form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:47
verses.text: But let us stop here and return to our subject.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:48
verses.text: "The earth was invisible and unfinished".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:49
verses.text: In saying "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth," the sacred writer passed over many things in silence, water, air, fire and the results from them, which, all forming in reality the true complement of the world, were, without doubt, made at the same time as the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:50
verses.text: By this silence, history wishes to train the activity or our intelligence, giving it a weak point for starting, to impel it to the discovery of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:51
verses.text: Thus, we are not told of the creation of water; but, as we are told that the earth was invisible, ask yourself what could have covered it, and prevented it from being seen? Fire could not conceal it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:52
verses.text: Fire brightens all about it, and spreads light rather than darkness around.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:53
verses.text: No more was it air that enveloped the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:54
verses.text: Air by nature is of little density and transparent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:55
verses.text: It receives all kinds of visible object, and transmits them to the spectators.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:56
verses.text: Only one supposition remains; that which floated on the surface of the earth was water—the fluid essence which had not yet been confined to its own place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:57
verses.text: Thus the earth was not only invisible; it was still incomplete.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:58
verses.text: Even today excessive damp is a hindrance to the productiveness of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:59
verses.text: The same cause at the same time prevents it from being seen, and from being complete, for the proper and natural adornment of the earth is its completion: corn waving in the valleys—meadows green with grass and rich with many coloured flowers—fertile glades and hill-tops shaded by forests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:60
verses.text: Of all this nothing was yet produced; the earth was in travail with it in virtue of the power that she had received from the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:61
verses.text: But she was waiting for the appointed time and the divine order to bring forth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:63
verses.text: "Darkness was upon the face of the deep".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:64
verses.text: A new source for fables and most impious imaginations if one distorts the sense of these words at the will of one's fancies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:65
verses.text: By "darkness" these wicked men do not understand what is meant in reality—air not illumined, the shadow produced by the interposition of a body, or finally a place for some reason deprived of light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:66
verses.text: For them "darkness" is an evil power, or rather the personification of evil, having his origin in himself in opposition to, and in perpetual struggle with, the goodness of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:67
verses.text: If God is light, they say, without any doubt the power which struggles against Him must be darkness, "Darkness" not owing its existence to a foreign origin, but an evil existing by itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:68
verses.text: "Darkness" is the enemy of souls, the primary cause of death, the adversary of virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:69
verses.text: The words of the Prophet, they say in their error, show that it exists and that it does not proceed from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:70
verses.text: From this what perverse and impious dogmas have been imagined! What grievous wolves, tearing the flock of the Lord, have sprung from these words to cast themselves upon souls! Is it not from hence that have come forth Marcions and Valentini, and the detestable heresy of the Manicheans, which you may without going far wrong call the putrid humour of the churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:71
verses.text: O man, why wander thus from the truth, and imagine for thyself that which will cause thy perdition? The word is simple and within the comprehension of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:72
verses.text: "The earth was invisible".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:73
verses.text: Why? Because the "deep" was spread over its surface.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:74
verses.text: What is "the deep"? A mass of water of extreme depth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:75
verses.text: But we know that we can see many bodies through clear and transparent water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:76
verses.text: How then was it that no part of the earth appeared through the water? Because the air which surrounded it was still without light and in darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:77
verses.text: The rays of the sun, penetrating the water, often allow us to see the pebbles which form the bed of the river, but in a dark night it is impossible for our glance to penetrate under the water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:78
verses.text: Thus, these words "the earth was invisible" are explained by those that follow; "the deep" covered it and itself was in darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:79
verses.text: Thus, the deep is not a multitude of hostile powers, as has been imagined; nor "darkness" an evil sovereign force in enmity with good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:80
verses.text: In reality two rival principles of equal power, if engaged without ceasing in a war of mutual attacks, will end in self destruction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:81
verses.text: But if one should gain the mastery it would completely annihilate the conquered.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:82
verses.text: Thus, to maintain the balance in the struggle between good and evil is to represent them as engaged in a war without end and in perpetual destruction, where the opponents are at the same time conquerors and conquered.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:83
verses.text: If good is the stronger, what is there to prevent evil being completely annihilated? But if that be the case, the very utterance of which is impious, I ask myself how it is that they themselves are not filled with horror to think that they have imagined such abominable blasphemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:84
verses.text: It is equally impious to say that evil has its origin from God; because the contrary cannot proceed from its contrary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:85
verses.text: Life does not engender death; darkness is not the origin of light; sickness is not the maker of health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:86
verses.text: In the changes of conditions there are transitions from one condition to the contrary; but in genesis each being proceeds from its like, and not from its contrary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:87
verses.text: If then evil is neither uncreate nor created by God, from whence comes its nature? Certainly that evil exists, no one living in the world will deny.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:88
verses.text: What shall we say then? Evil is not a living animated essence; it is the condition of the soul opposed to virtue, developed in the careless on account of their falling away from good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:90
verses.text: Do not then go beyond yourself to seek for evil, and imagine that there is an original nature of wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:91
verses.text: Each of us, let us acknowledge it, is the first author of his own vice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:92
verses.text: Among the ordinary events of life, some come naturally, like old age and sickness, others by chance like unforeseen occurrences, of which the origin is beyond ourselves, often sad, sometimes fortunate, as for instance the discovery of a treasure when digging a well, or the meeting of a mad dog when going to the market place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:93
verses.text: Others depend upon ourselves, such as ruling one's passions, or not putting a bridle on one's pleasures, to be master of our anger, or to raise the hand against him who irritates us, to tell the truth, or to lie, to have a sweet and well-regulated disposition, or to be fierce and swollen and exalted with pride.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:94
verses.text: Here you are the master of your actions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:95
verses.text: Do not look for the guiding cause beyond yourself, but recognise that evil, rightly so called, has no other origin than our voluntary falls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:96
verses.text: If it were involuntary, and did not depend upon ourselves, the laws would not have so much terror for the guilty, and the tribunals would not be so without pity when they condemn wretches according to the measure of their crimes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:97
verses.text: But enough concerning evil rightly so called.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:98
verses.text: Sickness, poverty, obscurity, death, finally all human afflictions, ought not to be ranked as evils; since we do not count among the greatest boons things which are their opposites.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:99
verses.text: Among these afflictions, some are the effect of nature, others have obviously been for many a source of advantage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:100
verses.text: Let us then be silent for the moment about these metaphors and allegories, and, simply following without vain curiosity the words of Holy Scripture, let us take from darkness the idea which it gives us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:101
verses.text: But reason asks, was darkness created with the world? Is it older than light? Why in spite of its inferiority has it preceded it? Darkness, we reply, did not exist in essence; it is a condition produced in the air by the withdrawal of light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:102
verses.text: What then is that light which disappeared suddenly from the world, so that darkness should cover the face of the deep? If anything had existed before the formation of this sensible and perishable world, no doubt we conclude it would have been in light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:103
verses.text: The orders of angels, the heavenly hosts, all intellectual natures named or unnamed, all the ministering spirits, did not live in darkness, but enjoyed a condition fitted for them in light and spiritual joy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:104
verses.text: No one will contradict this; least of all he who looks for celestial light as one of the rewards promised to virtue, the light which, as Solomon says, is always a light to the righteous, the light which made the Apostle say "Giving thanks unto the Father, which hath made us meet to be partakers of the inheritance of the saints in light".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:105
verses.text: Finally, if the condemned are sent into outer darkness evidently those who are made worthy of God's approval, are at rest in heavenly light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:106
verses.text: When then, according to the order of God, the heaven appeared, enveloping all that its circumference included, a vast and unbroken body separating outer things from those which it enclosed, it necessarily kept the space inside in darkness for want of communication with the outer light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:107
verses.text: Three things are, indeed, needed to form a shadow, light, a body, a dark place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:108
verses.text: The shadow of heaven forms the darkness of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:109
verses.text: Understand, I pray you, what I mean, by a simple example; by raising for yourself at mid-day a tent of some compact and impenetrable material, and shutting yourself up in it in sudden darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:110
verses.text: Suppose that original darkness was like this, not subsisting directly by itself, but resulting from some external causes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:111
verses.text: If it is said that it rested upon the deep, it is because the extremity of air naturally touches the surface of bodies; and as at that time the water covered everything, we are obliged to say that darkness was upon the face of the deep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:113
verses.text: And the Spirit of God was borne upon the face of the waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:114
verses.text: Does this spirit mean the diffusion of air? The sacred writer wishes to enumerate to you the elements of the world, to tell you that God created the heavens, the earth, water, and air and that the last was now diffused and in motion; or rather, that which is truer and confirmed by the authority of the ancients, by the Spirit of God, he means the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:115
verses.text: It is, as has been remarked, the special name, the name above all others that Scripture delights to give to the Holy Spirit, and always by the spirit of God the Holy Spirit is meant, the Spirit which completes the divine and blessed Trinity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:116
verses.text: You will find it better therefore to take it in this sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:117
verses.text: How then did the Spirit of God move upon the waters? The explanation that I am about to give you is not an original one, but that of a Syrian, who was as ignorant in the wisdom of this world as he was versed in the knowledge of the Truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:118
verses.text: He said, then, that the Syriac word was more expressive, and that being more analogous to the Hebrew term it was a nearer approach to the scriptural sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:119
verses.text: This is the meaning of the word; by "was borne" the Syrians, he says, understand: it cherished the nature of the waters as one sees a bird cover the eggs with her body and impart to them vital force from her own warmth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:120
verses.text: Such is, as nearly as possible, the meaning of these words—the Spirit was borne: let us understand, that is, prepared the nature of water to produce living beings: a sufficient proof for those who ask if the Holy Spirit took an active part in the creation of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:122
verses.text: And God said, Let there be light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:123
verses.text: The first word of God created the nature of light; it made darkness vanish, dispelled gloom, illuminated the world, and gave to all beings at the same time a sweet and gracious aspect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:124
verses.text: The heavens, until then enveloped in darkness, appeared with that beauty which they still present to our eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:125
verses.text: The air was lighted up, or rather made the light circulate mixed with its substance, and, distributing its splendour rapidly in every direction, so dispersed itself to its extreme limits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:126
verses.text: Up it sprang to the very aether and heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:127
verses.text: In an instant it lighted up the whole extent of the world, the North and the South, the East and the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:128
verses.text: For the aether also is such a subtle substance and so transparent that it needs not the space of a moment for light to pass through it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:129
verses.text: Just as it carries our sight instantaneously to the object of vision, so without the least interval, with a rapidity that thought cannot conceive, it receives these rays of light in its uttermost limits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:130
verses.text: With light the aether becomes more pleasing and the waters more limpid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:131
verses.text: These last, not content with receiving its splendour, return it by the reflection of light and in all directions send forth quivering flashes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:132
verses.text: The divine word gives every object a more cheerful and a more attractive appearance, just as when men in deep sea pour in oil they make the place about them clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:133
verses.text: So, with a single word and in one instant, the Creator of all things gave the boon of light to the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:134
verses.text: Let there be light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:135
verses.text: The order was itself an operation, and a state of things was brought into being, than which man's mind cannot even imagine a pleasanter one for our enjoyment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:136
verses.text: It must be well understood that when we speak of the voice, of the word, of the command of God, this divine language does not mean to us a sound which escapes from the organs of speech, a collision of air struck by the tongue; it is a simple sign of the will of God, and, if we give it the form of an order, it is only the better to impress the souls whom we instruct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:137
verses.text: And God saw the light, that it was good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:138
verses.text: How can we worthily praise light after the testimony given by the Creator to its goodness? The word, even among us, refers the judgment to the eyes, incapable of raising itself to the idea that the senses have already received.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:139
verses.text: But, if beauty in bodies results from symmetry of parts, and the harmonious appearance of colours, how in a simple and homogeneous essence like light, can this idea of beauty be preserved? Would not the symmetry in light be less shown in its parts than in the pleasure and delight at the sight of it? Such is also the beauty of gold, which it owes not to the happy mingling of its parts, but only to its beautiful colour which has a charm attractive to the eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:140
verses.text: Thus again, the evening star is the most beautiful of the stars: not that the parts of which it is composed form a harmonious whole; but thanks to the unalloyed and beautiful brightness which meets our eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:141
verses.text: And further, when God proclaimed the goodness of light, it was not in regard to the charm of the eye but as a provision for future advantage, because at that time there were as yet no eyes to judge of its beauty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:142
verses.text: "And God divided the light from the darkness;" that is to say, God gave them natures incapable of mixing, perpetually in opposition to each other, and put between them the widest space and distance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:144
verses.text: "And God called the light Day and the darkness he called Night".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:145
verses.text: Since the birth of the sun, the light that it diffuses in the air, when shining on our hemisphere, is day; and the shadow produced by its disappearance is night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:146
verses.text: But at that time it was not after the movement of the sun, but following this primitive light spread abroad in the air or withdrawn in a measure determined by God, that day came and was followed by night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:147
verses.text: "And the evening and the morning were the first day".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:148
verses.text: Evening is then the boundary common to day and night; and in the same way morning constitutes the approach of night to day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:149
verses.text: It was to give day the privileges of seniority that Scripture put the end of the first day before that of the first night, because night follows day: for, before the creation of light, the world was not in night, but in darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:150
verses.text: It is the opposite of day which was called night, and it did not receive its name until after day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:151
verses.text: Thus were created the evening and the morning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:152
verses.text: Scripture means the space of a day and a night, and afterwards no more says day and night, but calls them both under the name of the more important: a custom which you will find throughout Scripture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:153
verses.text: Everywhere the measure of time is counted by days, without mention of nights.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:154
verses.text: "The days of our years," says the Psalmist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:155
verses.text: "Few and evil have the days of the years of my life been," said Jacob, and elsewhere "all the days of my life".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:156
verses.text: Thus under the form of history the law is laid down for what is to follow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:157
verses.text: And the evening and the morning were one day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:158
verses.text: Why does Scripture say "one day the first day"? Before speaking to us of the second, the third, and the fourth days, would it not have been more natural to call that one the first which began the series? If it therefore says "one day," it is from a wish to determine the measure of day and night, and to combine the time that they contain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:159
verses.text: Now twenty-four hours fill up the space of one day—we mean of a day and of a night; and if, at the time of the solstices, they have not both an equal length, the time marked by Scripture does not the less circumscribe their duration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:160
verses.text: It is as though it said: twenty-four hours measure the space of a day, or that, in reality a day is the time that the heavens starting from one point take to return there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:161
verses.text: Thus, every time that, in the revolution of the sun, evening and morning occupy the world, their periodical succession never exceeds the space of one day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:162
verses.text: But must we believe in a mysterious reason for this? God who made the nature of time measured it out and determined it by intervals of days; and, wishing to give it a week as a measure, he ordered the week to revolve from period to period upon itself, to count the movement of time, forming the week of one day revolving seven times upon itself: a proper circle begins and ends with itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:163
verses.text: Such is also the character of eternity, to revolve upon itself and to end nowhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:164
verses.text: If then the beginning of time is called "one day" rather than "the first day," it is because Scripture wishes to establish its relationship with eternity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:165
verses.text: It was, in reality, fit and natural to call "one" the day whose character is to be one wholly separated and isolated from all the others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:166
verses.text: If Scripture speaks to us of many ages, saying everywhere, "age of age, and ages of ages," we do not see it enumerate them as first, second, and third.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:167
verses.text: It follows that we are hereby shown not so much limits, ends and succession of ages, as distinctions between various states and modes of action.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:168
verses.text: "The day of the Lord," Scripture says, "is great and very terrible," and elsewhere "Woe unto you that desire the day of the Lord: to what end is it for you? The day of the Lord is darkness and not light".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:169
verses.text: A day of darkness for those who are worthy of darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:170
verses.text: No; this day without evening, without succession and without end is not unknown to Scripture, and it is the day that the Psalmist calls the eighth day, because it is outside this time of weeks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:171
verses.text: Thus whether you call it day, or whether you call it eternity, you express the same idea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:172
verses.text: Give this state the name of day; there are not several, but only one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:173
verses.text: If you call it eternity still it is unique and not manifold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:174
verses.text: Thus it is in order that you may carry your thoughts forward towards a future life, that Scripture marks by the word "one" the day which is the type of eternity, the first fruits of days, the contemporary of light, the holy Lord's day honoured by the Resurrection of our Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:175
verses.text: And the evening and the morning were one day".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:176
verses.text: But, whilst I am conversing with you about the first evening of the world, evening takes me by surprise, and puts an end to my discourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:177
verses.text: May the Father of the true light, Who has adorned day with celestial light, Who has made the fire to shine which illuminates us during the night, Who reserves for us in the peace of a future age a spiritual and everlasting light, enlighten your hearts in the knowledge of truth, keep you from stumbling, and grant that "you may walk honestly as in the day".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 2:178
verses.text: Thus shall you shine as the sun in the midst of the glory of the saints, and I shall glory in you in the day of Christ, to Whom belong all glory and power for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:2
verses.text: On the Firmament.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:4
verses.text: We have now recounted the works of the first day, or rather of one day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:5
verses.text: Far be it from me indeed, to take from it the privilege it enjoys of having been for the Creator a day apart, a day which is not counted in the same order as the others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:6
verses.text: Our discussion yesterday treated of the works of this day, and divided the narrative so as to give you food for your souls in the morning, and joy in the evening.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:7
verses.text: To-day we pass on to the wonders of the second day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:8
verses.text: And here I do not wish to speak of the narrator's talent, but of the grace of Scripture, for the narrative is so naturally told that it pleases and delights all the friends of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:9
verses.text: It is this charm of truth which the Psalmist expresses so emphatically when he says, "How sweet are thy words unto my taste, yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:10
verses.text: Yesterday then, as far as we were able, we delighted our souls by conversing about the oracles of God, and now to-day we are met together again on the second day to contemplate the wonders of the second day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:11
verses.text: I know that many artisans, belonging to mechanical trades, are crowding around me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:12
verses.text: A day's labour hardly suffices to maintain them; therefore I am compelled to abridge my discourse, so as not to keep them too long from their work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:13
verses.text: What shall I say to them? The time which you lend to God is not lost: he will return it to you with large interest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:14
verses.text: Whatever difficulties may trouble you the Lord will disperse them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:15
verses.text: To those who have preferred spiritual welfare, He will give health of body, keenness of mind, success in business, and unbroken prosperity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:16
verses.text: And, even if in this life our efforts should not realise our hopes, the teachings of the Holy Spirit are none the less a rich treasure for the ages to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:17
verses.text: Deliver your heart, then, from the cares of this life and give close heed to my words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:18
verses.text: Of what avail will it be to you if you are here in the body, and your heart is anxious about your earthly treasure?  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:19
verses.text: And God said "Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:20
verses.text: Yesterday we heard God's decree, "Let there be light".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:21
verses.text: To-day it is, "Let there be a firmament".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:22
verses.text: There appears to be something more in this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:23
verses.text: The word is not limited to a simple command.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:24
verses.text: It lays down the reason necessitating the structure of the firmament: it is, it is said, to separate the waters from the waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:25
verses.text: And first let us ask how God speaks? Is it in our manner? Does His intelligence receive an impression from objects, and, after having conceived them, make them known by particular signs appropriate to each of them? Has He consequently recourse to the organs of voice to convey His thoughts? Is He obliged to strike the air by the articulate movements of the voice, to unveil the thought hidden in His heart? Would it not seem like an idle fable to say that God should need such a circuitous method to manifest His thoughts? And is it not more conformable with true religion to say, that the divine will and the first impetus of divine intelligence are the Word of God? It is He whom Scripture vaguely represents, to show us that God has not only wished to create the world, but to create it with the help of a co-operator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:26
verses.text: Scripture might continue the history as it is begun: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth; afterwards He created light, then He created the firmament.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:27
verses.text: But, by making God command and speak, the Scripture tacitly shows us Him to Whom this order and these words are addressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:28
verses.text: It is not that it grudges us the knowledge of the truth, but that it may kindle our desire by showing us some trace and indication of the mystery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:29
verses.text: We seize with delight, and carefully keep, the fruit of laborious efforts, whilst a possession easily attained is despised.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:30
verses.text: Such is the road and the course which Scripture follows to lead us to the idea of the Only begotten.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:31
verses.text: And certainly, God's immaterial nature had no need of the material language of voice, since His very thoughts could be transmitted to His fellow-worker.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:32
verses.text: What need then of speech, for those Who by thought alone could communicate their counsels to each other? Voice was made for hearing, and hearing for voice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:33
verses.text: Where there is neither air, nor tongue, nor ear, nor that winding canal which carries sounds to the seat of sensation in the head, there is no need for words: thoughts of the soul are sufficient to transmit the will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:34
verses.text: As I said then, this language is only a wise and ingenious contrivance to set our minds seeking the Person to whom the words are addressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:36
verses.text: In the second place, does the firmament that is called heaven differ from the firmament that God made in the beginning? Are there two heavens? The philosophers, who discuss heaven, would rather lose their tongues than grant this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:37
