verses.text: There is only one heaven, they pretend; and it is of a nature neither to admit of a second, nor of a third, nor of several others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:38
verses.text: The essence of the celestial body quite complete constitutes its vast unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:39
verses.text: Because, they say, every body which has a circular motion is one and finite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:40
verses.text: And if this body is used in the construction of the first heaven, there will be nothing left for the creation of a second or a third.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:41
verses.text: Here we see what those imagine who put under the Creator's hand uncreated matter; a lie that follows from the first fable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:42
verses.text: But we ask the Greek sages not to mock us before they are agreed among themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:43
verses.text: Because there are among them some who say there are infinite heavens and worlds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:44
verses.text: When grave demonstrations shall have upset their foolish system, when the laws of geometry shall have established that, according to the nature of heaven, it is impossible that there should be two, we shall only laugh the more at this elaborate scientific trifling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:45
verses.text: These learned men see not merely one bubble but several bubbles formed by the same cause, and they doubt the power of creative wisdom to bring several heavens into being! We find, however, if we raise our eyes towards the omnipotence of God, that the strength and grandeur of the heavens differ from the drops of water bubbling on the surface of a fountain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:46
verses.text: How ridiculous, then, is their argument of impossibility! As for myself, far from not believing in a second, I seek for the third whereon the blessed Paul was found worthy to gaze.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:47
verses.text: And does not the Psalmist in saying "heaven of heavens" give us an idea of their plurality? Is the plurality of heaven stranger than the seven circles through which nearly all the philosophers agree that the seven planets pass,—circles which they represent to us as placed in connection with each other like casks fitting the one into the other? These circles, they say, carried away in a direction contrary to that of the world, and striking the aether, make sweet and harmonious sounds, unequalled by the sweetest melody.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:48
verses.text: And if we ask them for the witness of the senses, what do they say? That we, accustomed to this noise from our birth, on account of hearing it always, have lost the sense of it; like men in smithies with their ears incessantly dinned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:49
verses.text: If I refuted this ingenious frivolity, the untruth of which is evident from the first word, it would seem as though I did not know the value of time, and mistrusted the intelligence of such an audience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:50
verses.text: But let me leave the vanity of outsiders to those who are without, and return to the theme proper to the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:51
verses.text: If we believe some of those who have preceded us, we have not here the creation of a new heaven, but a new account of the first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:52
verses.text: The reason they give is, that the earlier narrative briefly described the creation of heaven and earth; while here scripture relates in greater detail the manner in which each was created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:53
verses.text: I, however, since Scripture gives to this second heaven another name and its own function, maintain that it is different from the heaven which was made at the beginning; that it is of a stronger nature and of an especial use to the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:55
verses.text: "And God said, let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:56
verses.text: And God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:57
verses.text: Before laying hold of the meaning of Scripture let us try to meet objections from other quarters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:58
verses.text: We are asked how, if the firmament is a spherical body, as it appears to the eye, its convex circumference can contain the water which flows and circulates in higher regions? What shall we answer? One thing only: because the interior of a body presents a perfect concavity it does not necessarily follow that its exterior surface is spherical and smoothly rounded.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:59
verses.text: Look at the stone vaults of baths, and the structure of buildings of cave form; the dome, which forms the interior, does not prevent the roof from having ordinarily a flat surface.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:60
verses.text: Let these unfortunate men cease, then, from tormenting us and themselves about the impossibility of our retaining water in the higher regions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:61
verses.text: Now we must say something about the nature of the firmament, and why it received the order to hold the middle place between the waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:62
verses.text: Scripture constantly makes use of the word firmament to express extraordinary strength.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:63
verses.text: "The Lord my firmament and refuge".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:64
verses.text: "I have strengthened the pillars of it".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:65
verses.text: "Praise him in the firmament of his power".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:66
verses.text: The heathen writers thus call a strong body one which is compact and full, to distinguish it from the mathematical body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:67
verses.text: A mathematical body is a body which exists only in the three dimensions, breadth, depth, and height.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:68
verses.text: A firm body, on the contrary, adds resistance to the dimensions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:69
verses.text: It is the custom of Scripture to call firmament all that is strong and unyielding.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:70
verses.text: It even uses the word to denote the condensation of the air: He, it says, who strengthens the thunder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:71
verses.text: Scripture means by the strengthening of the thunder, the strength and resistance of the wind, which, enclosed in the hollows of the clouds, produces the noise of thunder when it breaks through with violence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:72
verses.text: Here then, according to me, is a firm substance, capable of retaining the fluid and unstable element water; and as, according to the common acceptation, it appears that the firmament owes its origin to water, we must not believe that it resembles frozen water or any other matter produced by the filtration of water; as, for example, rock crystal, which is said to owe its metamorphosis to excessive congelation, or the transparent stone which forms in mines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:73
verses.text: This pellucid stone, if one finds it in its natural perfection, without cracks inside, or the least spot of corruption, almost rivals the air in clearness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:74
verses.text: We cannot compare the firmament to one of these substances.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:75
verses.text: To hold such an opinion about celestial bodies would be childish and foolish; and although everything may be in everything, fire in earth, air in water, and of the other elements the one in the other; although none of those which come under our senses are pure and without mixture, either with the element which serves as a medium for it, or with that which is contrary to it; I, nevertheless, dare not affirm that the firmament was formed of one of these simple substances, or of a mixture of them, for I am taught by Scripture not to allow my imagination to wander too far afield.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:76
verses.text: But do not let us forget to remark that, after these divine words "let there be a firmament," it is not said "and the firmament was made" but, "and God made the firmament, and divided the waters".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:77
verses.text: Hear, O ye deaf! See, O ye blind!—who, then, is deaf? He who does not hear this startling voice of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:78
verses.text: Who is blind? He who does not see such clear proofs of the Only begotten.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:79
verses.text: "Let there be a firmament".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:80
verses.text: It is the voice of the primary and principal Cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:81
verses.text: "And God made the firmament".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:82
verses.text: Here is a witness to the active and creative power of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:84
verses.text: But let us continue our explanation: "Let it divide the waters from the waters".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:85
verses.text: The mass of waters, which from all directions flowed over the earth, and was suspended in the air, was infinite, so that there was no proportion between it and the other elements.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:86
verses.text: Thus, as it has been already said, the abyss covered the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:87
verses.text: We give the reason for this abundance of water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:88
verses.text: None of you assuredly will attack our opinion; not even those who have the most cultivated minds, and whose piercing eye can penetrate this perishable and fleeting nature; you will not accuse me of advancing impossible or imaginary theories, nor will you ask me upon what foundation the fluid element rests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:89
verses.text: By the same reason which makes them attract the earth, heavier than water, from the extremities of the world to suspend it in the centre, they will grant us without doubt that it is due both to its natural attraction downwards and its general equilibrium, that this immense quantity of water rests motionless upon the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:90
verses.text: Therefore the prodigious mass of waters was spread around the earth; not in proportion with it and infinitely larger, thanks to the foresight of the supreme Artificer, Who, from the beginning, foresaw what was to come, and at the first provided all for the future needs of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:91
verses.text: But what need was there for this superabundance of water? The essence of fire is necessary for the world, not only in the economy of earthly produce, but for the completion of the universe; for it would be imperfect if the most powerful and the most vital of its elements were lacking.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:92
verses.text: Now fire and water are hostile to and destructive of each other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:93
verses.text: Fire, if it is the stronger, destroys water, and water, if in greater abundance, destroys fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:94
verses.text: As, therefore, it was necessary to avoid an open struggle between these elements, so as not to bring about the dissolution of the universe by the total disappearance of one or the other, the sovereign Disposer created such a quantity of water that in spite of constant diminution from the effects of fire, it could last until the time fixed for the destruction of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:95
verses.text: He who planned all with weight and measure, He who, according to the word of Job, knows the number of the drops of rain, knew how long His work would last, and for how much consumption of fire He ought to allow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:96
verses.text: This is the reason of the abundance of water at the creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:97
verses.text: Further, there is no one so strange to life as to need to learn the reason why fire is essential to the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:98
verses.text: Not only all the arts which support life, the art of weaving, that of shoemaking, of architecture, of agriculture, have need of the help of fire, but the vegetation of trees, the ripening of fruits, the breeding of land and water animals, and their nourishment, all existed from heat from the beginning, and have been since maintained by the action of heat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:99
verses.text: The creation of heat was then indispensable for the formation and the preservation of beings, and the abundance of waters was no less so in the presence of the constant and inevitable consumption by fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:101
verses.text: Survey creation; you will see the power of heat reigning over all that is born and perishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:102
verses.text: On account of it comes all the water spread over the earth, as well as that which is beyond our sight and is dispersed in the depths of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:103
verses.text: On account of it are abundance of fountains, springs or wells, courses of rivers, both mountain torrents and ever flowing streams, for the storing of moisture in many and various reservoirs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:104
verses.text: From the East, from the winter solstice flows the Indus, the greatest river of the earth, according to geographers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:105
verses.text: From the middle of the East proceed the Bactrus, the Choaspes, and the Araxes, from which the Tanais detaches itself to fall into the Palus-Maeotis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:106
verses.text: Add to these the Phasis which descends from Mount Caucasus, and countless other rivers, which, from northern regions, flow into the Euxine Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:107
verses.text: From the warm countries of the West, from the foot of the Pyrenees, arise the Tartessus and the Ister, of which the one discharges itself into the sea beyond the Pillars and the other, after flowing through Europe, falls into Euxine Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:108
verses.text: Is there any need to enumerate those which the Ripaean mountains pour forth in the heart of Scythia, the Rhone, and so many other rivers, all navigable, which after having watered the countries of the western Gauls and of Celts and of the neighbouring barbarians, flow into the Western sea? And others from the higher regions of the South flow through Ethiopia, to discharge themselves some into our sea, others into inaccessible seas, the aegon the Nyses, the Chremetes, and above all the Nile, which is not of the character of a river when, like a sea, it inundates Egypt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:109
verses.text: Thus the habitable part of our earth is surrounded by water, linked together by vast seas and irrigated by countless perennial rivers, thanks to the ineffable wisdom of Him Who ordered all to prevent this rival element to fire from being entirely destroyed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:110
verses.text: However, a time will come, when all shall be consumed by fire; as Isaiah says of the God of the universe in these words, "That saith to the deep, Be dry, and I will dry up thy rivers".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:111
verses.text: Reject then the foolish wisdom of this world, and receive with me the more simple but infallible doctrine of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:113
verses.text: Therefore we read: "Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:114
verses.text: I have said what the word firmament in Scripture means.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:115
verses.text: It is not in reality a firm and solid substance which has weight and resistance; this name would otherwise have better suited the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:116
verses.text: But, as the substance of superincumbent bodies is light, without consistency, and cannot be grasped by any one of our senses, it is in comparison with these pure and imperceptible substances that the firmament has received its name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:117
verses.text: Imagine a place fit to divide the moisture, sending it, if pure and filtered, into higher regions, and making it fall, if it is dense and earthy; to the end that by the gradual withdrawal of the moist particles the same temperature may be preserved from the beginning to the end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:118
verses.text: You do not believe in this prodigious quantity of water; but you do not take into account the prodigious quantity of heat, less considerable no doubt in bulk, but exceedingly powerful nevertheless, if you consider it as destructive of moisture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:119
verses.text: It attracts surrounding moisture, as the melon shows us, and consumes it as quickly when attracted, as the flame of the lamp draws to it the fuel supplied by the wick and burns it up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:120
verses.text: Who doubts that the aether is an ardent fire? If an impassable limit had not been assigned to it by the Creator, what would prevent it from setting on fire and consuming all that is near it, and absorbing all the moisture from existing things? The aerial waters which veil the heavens with vapours that are sent forth by rivers, fountains, marshes, lakes, and seas, prevent the aether from invading and burning up the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:121
verses.text: Thus we see even this sun, in the summer season, dry up in a moment a damp and marshy country, and make it perfectly arid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:122
verses.text: What has become of all the water? Let these masters of omniscience tell us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:123
verses.text: Is it not plain to every one that it has risen in vapour, and has been consumed by the heat of the sun? They say, none the less, that even the sun is without heat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:124
verses.text: What time they lose in words! And see what proof they lean upon to resist what is perfectly plain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:125
verses.text: Its colour is white, and neither reddish nor yellow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:126
verses.text: It is not then fiery by nature, and its heat results, they say, from the velocity of its rotation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:127
verses.text: What do they gain? That the sun does not seem to absorb moisture? I do not, however, reject this statement, although it is false, because it helps my argument.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:128
verses.text: I said that the consumption of heat required this prodigious quantity of water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:129
verses.text: That the sun owes its heat to its nature, or that heat results from its action, makes no difference, provided that it produces the same effects upon the same matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:130
verses.text: If you kindle fire by rubbing two pieces of wood together, or if you light them by holding them to a flame, you will have absolutely the same effect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:131
verses.text: Besides, we see that the great wisdom of Him who governs all, makes the sun travel from one region to another, for fear that, if it remained always in the same place, its excessive heat would destroy the order of the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:132
verses.text: Now it passes into southern regions about the time of the winter solstice, now it returns to the sign of the equinox; from thence it betakes itself to northern regions during the summer solstice, and keeps up by this imperceptible passage a pleasant temperature throughout all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:133
verses.text: Let the learned people see if they do not disagree among themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:134
verses.text: The water which the sun consumes is, they say, what prevents the sea from rising and flooding the rivers; the warmth of the sun leaves behind the salts and the bitterness of the waters, and absorbs from them the pure and drinkable particles, thanks to the singular virtue of this planet in attracting all that is light and in allowing to fall, like mud and sediment, all which is thick and earthy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:135
verses.text: From thence come the bitterness, the salt taste and the power of withering and drying up which are characteristic of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:136
verses.text: While as is notorious, they hold these views, they shift their ground and say that moisture cannot be lessened by the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:138
verses.text: "And God called the firmament heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:139
verses.text: The nature of right belongs to another, and the firmament only shares it on account of its resemblance to heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:140
verses.text: We often find the visible region called heaven, on account of the density and continuity of the air within our ken, and deriving its name "heaven" from the word which means to see.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:141
verses.text: It is of it that Scripture says, "The fowl of the air," "Fowl that may fly…in the open firmament of heaven;" and, elsewhere, "They mount up to heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:142
verses.text: Moses, blessing the tribe of Joseph, desires for it the fruits and the dews of heaven, of the suns of summer and the conjunctions of the moon, and blessings from the tops of the mountains and from the everlasting hills, in one word, from all which fertilises the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:143
verses.text: In the curses on Israel it is said, "And thy heaven that is over thy head shall be brass".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:144
verses.text: What does this mean? It threatens him with a complete drought, with an absence of the aerial waters which cause the fruits of the earth to be brought forth and to grow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:145
verses.text: Since, then, Scripture says that the dew or the rain falls from heaven, we understand that it is from those waters which have been ordered to occupy the higher regions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:146
verses.text: When the exhalations from the earth, gathered together in the heights of the air, are condensed under the pressure of the wind, this aerial moisture diffuses itself in vaporous and light clouds; then mingling again, it forms drops which fall, dragged down by their own weight; and this is the origin of rain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:147
verses.text: When water beaten by the violence of the wind, changes into foam, and passing through excessive cold quite freezes, it breaks the cloud, and falls as snow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:148
verses.text: You can thus account for all the moist substances that the air suspends over our heads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:149
verses.text: And do not let any one compare with the inquisitive discussions of philosophers upon the heavens, the simple and inartificial character of the utterances of the Spirit; as the beauty of chaste women surpasses that of a harlot, so our arguments are superior to those of our opponents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:150
verses.text: They only seek to persuade by forced reasoning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:151
verses.text: With us truth presents itself naked and without artifice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:152
verses.text: But why torment ourselves to refute the errors of philosophers, when it is sufficient to produce their mutually contradictory books, and, as quiet spectators, to watch the war? For those thinkers are not less numerous, nor less celebrated, nor more sober in speech in fighting their adversaries, who say that the universe is being consumed by fire, and that from the seeds which remain in the ashes of the burnt world all is being brought to life again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:153
verses.text: Hence in the world there is destruction and palingenesis to infinity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:154
verses.text: All, equally far from the truth, find each on their side by-ways which lead them to error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:156
verses.text: But as far as concerns the separation of the waters I am obliged to contest the opinion of certain writers in the Church who, under the shadow of high and sublime conceptions, have launched out into metaphor, and have only seen in the waters a figure to denote spiritual and incorporeal powers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:157
verses.text: In the higher regions, above the firmament, dwell the better; in the lower regions, earth and matter are the dwelling place of the malignant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:158
verses.text: So, say they, God is praised by the waters that are above the heaven, that is to say, by the good powers, the purity of whose soul makes them worthy to sing the praises of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:159
verses.text: And the waters which are under the heaven represent the wicked spirits, who from their natural height have fallen into the abyss of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:160
verses.text: Turbulent, seditious, agitated by the tumultuous waves of passion, they have received the name of sea, because of the instability and the inconstancy of their movements.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:161
verses.text: Let us reject these theories as dreams and old women's tales.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:162
verses.text: Let us understand that by water water is meant; for the dividing of the waters by the firmament let us accept the reason which has been given us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:163
verses.text: Although, however, waters above the heaven are invited to give glory to the Lord of the Universe, do not let us think of them as intelligent beings; the heavens are not alive because they "declare the glory of God," nor the firmament a sensible being because it "sheweth His handiwork".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:164
verses.text: And if they tell you that the heavens mean contemplative powers, and the firmament active powers which produce good, we admire the theory as ingenious without being able to acknowledge the truth of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:165
verses.text: For thus dew, the frost, cold and heat, which in Daniel are ordered to praise the Creator of all things, will be intelligent and invisible natures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:166
verses.text: But this is only a figure, accepted as such by enlightened minds, to complete the glory of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:167
verses.text: Besides, the waters above the heavens, these waters privileged by the virtue which they possess in themselves, are not the only waters to celebrate the praises of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:168
verses.text: "Praise the Lord from the earth, ye dragons and all deeps".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:169
verses.text: Thus the singer of the Psalms does not reject the deeps which our inventors of allegories rank in the divisions of evil; he admits them to the universal choir of creation, and the deeps sing in their language a harmonious hymn to the glory of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:171
verses.text: "And God saw that it was good".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:172
verses.text: God does not judge of the beauty of His work by the charm of the eyes, and He does not form the same idea of beauty that we do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:173
verses.text: What He esteems beautiful is that which presents in its perfection all the fitness of art, and that which tends to the usefulness of its end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:174
verses.text: He, then, who proposed to Himself a manifest design in His works, approved each one of them, as fulfilling its end in accordance with His creative purpose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:175
verses.text: A hand, an eye, or any portion of a statue lying apart from the rest, would look beautiful to no one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:176
verses.text: But if each be restored to its own place, the beauty of proportion, until now almost unperceived, would strike even the most uncultivated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:177
verses.text: But the artist, before uniting the parts of his work, distinguishes and recognises the beauty of each of them, thinking of the object that he has in view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:178
verses.text: It is thus that Scripture depicts to us the Supreme Artist, praising each one of His works; soon, when His work is complete, He will accord well deserved praise to the whole together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:179
verses.text: Let me here end my discourse on the second day, to allow my industrious hearers to examine what they have just heard.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:180
verses.text: May their memory retain it for the profit of their soul; may they by careful meditation inwardly digest and benefit by what I say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:181
verses.text: As for those who live by their work, let me allow them to attend all day to their business, so that they may come, with a soul free from anxiety, to the banquet of my discourse in the evening.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:182
verses.text: May God who, after having made such great things, put such weak words in my mouth, grant you the intelligence of His truth, so that you may raise yourselves from visible things to the invisible Being, and that the grandeur and beauty of creatures may give you a just idea of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:183
verses.text: For the visible things of Him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, and His power and divinity are eternal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:184
verses.text: Thus earth, air, sky, water, day, night, all visible things, remind us of who is our Benefactor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 3:185
verses.text: We shall not therefore give occasion to sin, we shall not give place to the enemy within us, if by unbroken recollection we keep God ever dwelling in our hearts, to Whom be all glory and all adoration, now and for ever, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:2
verses.text: Upon the gathering together of the waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:4
verses.text: There are towns where the inhabitants, from dawn to eve, feast their eyes on the tricks of innumerable conjurors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:5
verses.text: They are never tired of hearing dissolute songs which cause much impurity to spring up in their souls, and they are often called happy, because they neglect the cares of business and trades useful to life, and pass the time, which is assigned to them on this earth, in idleness and pleasure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:6
verses.text: They do not know that a theatre full of impure sights is, for those who sit there, a common school of vice; that these melodious and meretricious songs insinuate themselves into men's souls, and all who hear them, eager to imitate the notes of harpers and pipers, are filled with filthiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:7
verses.text: Some others, who are wild after horses, think they are backing their horses in their dreams; they harness their chariots, change their drivers, and even in sleep are not free from the folly of the day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:8
verses.text: And shall we, whom the Lord, the great worker of marvels, calls to the contemplation of His own works, tire of looking at them, or be slow to hear the words of the Holy Spirit? Shall we not rather stand around the vast and varied workshop of divine creation and, carried back in mind to the times of old, shall we not view all the order of creation? Heaven, poised like a dome, to quote the words of the prophet; earth, this immense mass which rests upon itself; the air around it, of a soft and fluid nature, a true and continual nourishment for all who breathe it, of such tenuity that it yields and opens at the least movement of the body, opposing no resistance to our motions, while, in a moment, it streams back to its place, behind those who cleave it; water, finally, that supplies drink for man, or may be designed for our other needs, and the marvellous gathering together of it into definite places which have been assigned to it: such is the spectacle which the words which I have just read will show you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:10
verses.text: "And God said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear, and it was so".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:11
verses.text: And the water which was under the heaven gathered together unto one place; "And God called the dry land earth and the gathering together of the waters called He seas".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:12
verses.text: What trouble you have given me in my previous discourses by asking me why the earth was invisible, why all bodies are naturally endued with colour, and why all colour comes under the sense of sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:13
verses.text: And, perhaps, my reason did not appear sufficient to you, when I said that the earth, without being naturally invisible, was so to us, because of the mass of water that entirely covered it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:14
verses.text: Hear then how Scripture explains itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:15
verses.text: "Let the waters be gathered together, and let the dry land appear".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:16
verses.text: The veil is lifted and allows the earth, hitherto invisible, to be seen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:17
verses.text: Perhaps you will ask me new questions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:18
verses.text: And first, is it not a law of nature that water flows downwards? Why, then, does Scripture refer this to the fiat of the Creator? As long as water is spread over a level surface, it does not flow; it is immovable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:19
verses.text: But when it finds any slope, immediately the foremost portion falls, then the one that follows takes its place, and that one is itself replaced by a third.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:20
verses.text: Thus incessantly they flow, pressing the one on the other, and the rapidity of their course is in proportion to the mass of water that is being carried, and the declivity down which it is borne.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:21
verses.text: If such is the nature of water, it was supererogatory to command it to gather into one place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:22
verses.text: It was bound, on account of its natural instability, to fall into the most hollow part of the earth and not to stop until the levelling of its surface.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:23
verses.text: We see how there is nothing so level as the surface of water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:24
verses.text: Besides, they add, how did the waters receive an order to gather into one place, when we see several seas, separated from each other by the greatest distances? To the first question I reply: Since God's command, you know perfectly well the motion of water; you know that it is unsteady and unstable and falls naturally over declivities and into hollow places.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:25
verses.text: But what was its nature before this command made it take its course? You do not know yourself, and you have heard from no eye-witness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:26
verses.text: Think, in reality, that a word of God makes the nature, and that this order is for the creature a direction for its future course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:27
verses.text: There was only one creation of day and night, and since that moment they have incessantly succeeded each other and divided time into equal parts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:29
verses.text: "Let the waters be gathered together".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:30
verses.text: It was ordered that it should be the natural property of water to flow, and in obedience to this order, the waters are never weary in their course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:31
verses.text: In speaking thus, I have only in view the flowing property of waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:32
verses.text: Some flow of their own accord like springs and rivers, others are collected and stationary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:33
verses.text: But I speak now of flowing waters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:34
verses.text: "Let the waters be gathered together unto one place".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:35
verses.text: Have you never thought, when standing near a spring which is sending forth water abundantly, Who makes this water spring from the bowels of the earth? Who forced it up? Where are the store-houses which send it forth? To what place is it hastening? How is it that it is never exhausted here, and never overflows there? All this comes from that first command; it was for the waters a signal for their course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:36
verses.text: In all the story of the waters remember this first order, "let the waters be gathered together".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:37
verses.text: To take their assigned places they were obliged to flow, and, once arrived there, to remain in their place and not to go farther.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:38
verses.text: Thus in the language of Ecclesiastes, "All the waters run into the sea; yet the sea is not full".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:39
verses.text: Waters flow in virtue of God's order, and the sea is enclosed in limits according to this first law, "Let the waters be gathered together unto one place".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:40
verses.text: For fear the water should spread beyond its bed, and in its successive invasions cover one by one all countries, and end by flooding the whole earth, it received the order to gather unto one place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:41
verses.text: Thus we often see the furious sea raising mighty waves to the heaven, and, when once it has touched the shore, break its impetuosity in foam and retire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:42
verses.text: "Fear ye not me, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:43
verses.text: …which have placed the sand for the bound of the sea".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:44
verses.text: A grain of sand, the weakest thing possible, curbs the violence of the ocean.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:45
verses.text: For what would prevent the Red Sea from invading the whole of Egypt, which lies lower, and uniting itself to the other sea which bathes its shores, were it not fettered by the fiat of the Creator? And if I say that Egypt is lower than the Red Sea, it is because experience has convinced us of it every time that an attempt has been made to join the sea of Egypt to the Indian Ocean, of which the Red Sea is a part.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:46
verses.text: Thus we have renounced this enterprise, as also have the Egyptian Sesostris, who conceived the idea, and Darius the Mede who afterwards wished to carry it out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:47
verses.text: I report this fact to make you understand the full force of the command, "Let the waters be gathered unto one place"; that is to say, let there be no other gathering, and, once gathered, let them not disperse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:49
verses.text: To say that the waters were gathered in one place indicates that previously they were scattered in many places.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:50
verses.text: The mountains, intersected by deep ravines, accumulated water in their valleys, when from every direction the waters betook themselves to the one gathering place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:51
verses.text: What vast plains, in their extent resembling wide seas, what valleys, what cavities hollowed in many different ways, at that time full of water, must have been emptied by the command of God! But we must not therefore say, that if the water covered the face of the earth, all the basins which have since received the sea were originally full.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:52
verses.text: Where can the gathering of the waters have come from if the basins were already full? These basins, we reply, were only prepared at the moment when the water had to unite in a single mass.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:53
verses.text: At that time the sea which is beyond Gadeira and the vast ocean, so dreaded by navigators, which surrounds the isle of Britain and western Spain, did not exist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:54
verses.text: But, all of a sudden, God created this vast space, and the mass of waters flowed in.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:55
verses.text: Now if our explanation of the creation of the world may appear contrary to experience, (because it is evident that all the waters did not flow together in one place,) many answers may be made, all obvious as soon as they are stated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:56
verses.text: Perhaps it is even ridiculous to reply to such objections.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:57
verses.text: Ought they to bring forward in opposition ponds and accumulations of rain water, and think that this is enough to upset our reasonings? Evidently the chief and most complete affluence of the waters was what received the name of gathering unto one place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:58
verses.text: For wells are also gathering places for water, made by the hand of man to receive the moisture diffused in the hollow of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:59
verses.text: This name of gathering does not mean any chance massing of water, but the greatest and most important one, wherein the element is shewn collected together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:60
verses.text: In the same way that fire, in spite of its being divided into minute particles which are sufficient for our needs here, is spread in a mass in the aether; in the same way that air, in spite of a like minute division, has occupied the region round the earth; so also water, in spite of the small amount spread abroad everywhere, only forms one gathering together, that which separates the whole element from the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:61
verses.text: Without doubt the lakes as well those of the northern regions and those that are to be found in Greece, in Macedonia, in Bithynia and in Palestine, are gatherings together of waters; but here it means the greatest of all, that gathering the extent of which equals that of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:62
verses.text: The first contain a great quantity of water; no one will deny this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:63
verses.text: Nevertheless no one could reasonably give them the name of seas, not even if they are like the great sea, charged with salt and sand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:64
verses.text: They instance for example, the Lacus Asphaltitis in Judaea, and the Serbonian lake which extends between Egypt and Palestine in the Arabian desert.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:65
verses.text: These are lakes, and there is only one sea, as those affirm who have travelled round the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:66
verses.text: Although some authorities think the Hyrcanian and Caspian Seas are enclosed in their own boundaries, if we are to believe the geographers, they communicate with each other and together discharge themselves into the Great Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:67
verses.text: It is thus that, according to their account, the Red Sea and that beyond Gadeira only form one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:68
verses.text: Then why did God call the different masses of water seas? This is the reason; the waters flowed into one place, and their different accumulations, that is to say, the gulfs that the earth embraced in her folds, received from the Lord the name of seas: North Sea, South Sea, Eastern Sea, and Western Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:69
verses.text: The seas have even their own names, the Euxine, the Propontis, the Hellespont, the aegean, the Ionian, the Sardinian, the Sicilian, the Tyrrhene, and many other names of which an exact enumeration would now be too long, and quite out of place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:70
verses.text: See why God calls the gathering together of waters seas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:71
verses.text: But let us return to the point from which the course of my argument has diverted me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:73
verses.text: And God said: "Let the waters be gathered together unto one place and let the dry land appear".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:74
verses.text: He did not say let the earth appear, so as not to show itself again without form, mud-like, and in combination with the water, nor yet endued with proper form and virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:75
verses.text: At the same time, lest we should attribute the drying of the earth to the sun, the Creator shows it to us dried before the creation of the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:76
verses.text: Let us follow the thought Scripture gives us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:77
verses.text: Not only the water which was covering the earth flowed off from it, but all that which had filtered into its depths withdrew in obedience to the irresistible order of the sovereign Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:78
verses.text: And it was so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:79
verses.text: This is quite enough to show that the Creator's voice had effect: however, in several editions, there is added "And the water which was under the heavens gathered itself unto one place and the dry land was seen;" words that other interpreters have not given, and which do not appear conformable to Hebrew usage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:80
verses.text: In fact, after the assertion, "and it was so," it is superfluous to repeat exactly the same thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:81
verses.text: In accurate copies these words are marked with an obelus, which is the sign of rejection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:82
verses.text: "And God called the dry land earth; and the gathering together of the waters called He seas".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:83
verses.text: Why does Scripture say above that the waters were gathered together unto one place, and that the dry earth appeared? Why does it add here the dry land appeared, and God gave it the name of earth? It is that dryness is the property which appears to characterize the nature of the subject, whilst the word earth is only its simple name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:84
verses.text: Just as reason is the distinctive faculty of man, and the word man serves to designate the being gifted with this faculty, so dryness is the special and peculiar quality of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:85
verses.text: The element essentially dry receives therefore the name of earth, as the animal who has a neigh for a characteristic cry is called a horse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:86
verses.text: The other elements, like the earth, have received some peculiar property which distinguishes them from the rest, and makes them known for what they are.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:87
verses.text: Thus water has cold for its distinguishing property; air, moisture; fire, heat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:88
verses.text: But this theory really applies only to the primitive elements of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:89
verses.text: The elements which contribute to the formation of bodies, and come under our senses, show us these qualities in combination, and in the whole of nature our eyes and senses can find nothing which is completely singular, simple and pure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:90
verses.text: Earth is at the same time dry and cold; water, cold and moist; air, moist and warm; fire, warm and dry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:91
verses.text: It is by the combination of their qualities that the different elements can mingle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:92
verses.text: Thanks to a common quality each of them mixes with a neighbouring element, and this natural alliance attaches it to the contrary element.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:93
verses.text: For example, earth, which is at the same time dry and cold, finds in cold a relationship which unites it to water, and by the means of water unites itself to air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:94
verses.text: Water placed between the two, appears to give each a hand, and, on account of its double quality, allies itself to earth by cold and to air by moisture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:95
verses.text: Air, in its turn, takes the middle place and plays the part of a mediator between the inimical natures of water and fire, united to the first by moisture, and to the second by heat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:96
verses.text: Finally fire, of a nature at the same time warm and dry, is linked to air by warmth, and by its dryness reunites itself to the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:97
verses.text: And from this accord and from this mutual mixture of elements, results a circle and an harmonious choir whence each of the elements deserves its name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:98
verses.text: I have said this in order to explain why God has given to the dry land the name of earth, without however calling the earth dry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:99
verses.text: It is because dryness is not one of those qualities which the earth acquired afterwards, but one of those which constituted its essence from the beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:100
verses.text: Now that which causes a body to exist, is naturally antecedent to its posterior qualities and has a pre-eminence over them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:101
verses.text: It is then with reason that God chose the most ancient characteristic of the earth whereby to designate it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:103
verses.text: "And God saw that it was good".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:104
verses.text: Scripture does not merely wish to say that a pleasing aspect of the sea presented itself to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:105
verses.text: It is not with eyes that the Creator views the beauty of His works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:106
verses.text: He contemplates them in His ineffable wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:107
verses.text: A fair sight is the sea all bright in a settled calm; fair too, when, ruffled by a light breeze of wind, its surface shows tints of purple and azure,—when, instead of lashing with violence the neighbouring shores, it seems to kiss them with peaceful caresses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:108
verses.text: However, it is not in this that Scripture makes God find the goodness and charm of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:109
verses.text: Here it is the purpose of the work which makes the goodness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:110
verses.text: In the first place sea water is the source of all the moisture of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:111
verses.text: It filters through imperceptible conduits, as is proved by the subterranean openings and caves whither its waves penetrate; it is received in oblique and sinuous canals; then, driven out by the wind, it rises to the surface of the earth, and breaks it, having become drinkable and free from its bitterness by this long percolation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:112
verses.text: Often, moved by the same cause, it springs even from mines that it has crossed, deriving warmth from them, and rises boiling, and bursts forth of a burning heat, as may be seen in islands and on the sea coast; even inland in certain places, in the neighbourhood of rivers, to compare little things with great, almost the same phenomena occur.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:113
verses.text: To what do these words tend? To prove that the earth is all undermined with invisible conduits, where the water travels everywhere underground from the sources of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:115
verses.text: Thus, in the eyes of God, the sea is good, because it makes the under current of moisture in the depths of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:116
verses.text: It is good again, because from all sides it receives the rivers without exceeding its limits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:117
verses.text: It is good, because it is the origin and source of the waters in the air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:118
verses.text: Warmed by the rays of the sun, it escapes in vapour, is attracted into the high regions of the air, and is there cooled on account of its rising high above the refraction of the rays from the ground, and, the shade of the clouds adding to this refrigeration, it is changed into rain and fattens the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:119
verses.text: If people are incredulous, let them look at caldrons on the fire, which, though full of water, are often left empty because all the water is boiled and resolved into vapour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:120
verses.text: Sailors, too, boil even sea water, collecting the vapour in sponges, to quench their thirst in pressing need.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:121
verses.text: Finally the sea is good in the eyes of God, because it girdles the isles, of which it forms at the same time the rampart and the beauty, because it brings together the most distant parts of the earth, and facilitates the inter-communication of mariners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:122
verses.text: By this means it gives us the boon of general information, supplies the merchant with his wealth, and easily provides for the necessities of life, allowing the rich to export their superfluities, and blessing the poor with the supply of what they lack.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:123
verses.text: But whence do I perceive the goodness of the Ocean, as it appeared in the eyes of the Creator? If the Ocean is good and worthy of praise before God, how much more beautiful is the assembly of a Church like this, where the voices of men, of children, and of women, arise in our prayers to God mingling and resounding like the waves which beat upon the shore.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:124
verses.text: This Church also enjoys a profound calm, and malicious spirits cannot trouble it with the breath of heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 4:125
verses.text: Deserve, then, the approbation of the Lord by remaining faithful to such good guidance, in our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom be glory and power for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:2
verses.text: The Germination of the Earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:4
verses.text: "And God said Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind, whose seed is in itself".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:5
verses.text: It was deep wisdom that commanded the earth, when it rested after discharging the weight of the waters, first to bring forth grass, then wood as we see it doing still at this time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:6
verses.text: For the voice that was then heard and this command were as a natural and permanent law for it; it gave fertility and the power to produce fruit for all ages to come; "Let the earth bring forth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:7
verses.text: The production of vegetables shows first germination.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:8
verses.text: When the germs begin to sprout they form grass; this develops and becomes a plant, which insensibly receives its different articulations, and reaches its maturity in the seed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:9
verses.text: Thus all things which sprout and are green are developed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:10
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth green grass".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:11
verses.text: Let the earth bring forth by itself without having any need of help from without.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:12
verses.text: Some consider the sun as the source of all productiveness on the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:13
verses.text: It is, they say, the action of the sun's heat which attracts the vital force from the centre of the earth to the surface.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:14
verses.text: The reason why the adornment of the earth was before the sun is the following; that those who worship the sun, as the source of life, may renounce their error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:15
verses.text: If they be well persuaded that the earth was adorned before the genesis of the sun, they will retract their unbounded admiration for it, because they see grass and plants vegetate before it rose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:16
verses.text: If then the food for the flocks was prepared, did our race appear less worthy of a like solicitude? He, who provided pasture for horses and cattle, thought before all of your riches and pleasures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:17
verses.text: If he fed your cattle, it was to provide for all the needs of your life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:18
verses.text: And what object was there in the bringing forth of grain, if not for your subsistence? Moreover, many grasses and vegetables serve for the food of man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:20
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass yielding seed after his kind".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:21
verses.text: So that although some kind of grass is of service to animals, even their gain is our gain too, and seeds are especially designed for our use.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:22
verses.text: Such is the true meaning of the words that I have quoted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:23
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed after his kind".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:24
verses.text: In this manner we can re-establish the order of the words, of which the construction seems faulty in the actual version, and the economy of nature will be rigorously observed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:25
verses.text: In fact, first comes germination, then verdure, then the growth of the plant, which after having attained its full growth arrives at perfection in seed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:26
verses.text: How then, they say, can Scripture describe all the plants of the earth as seed-bearing, when the reed, couch-grass, mint, crocus, garlic, and the flowering rush and countless other species, produce no seed? To this we reply that many vegetables have their seminal virtue in the lower part and in the roots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:27
verses.text: The need, for example, after its annual growth sends forth a protuberance from its roots, which takes the place of seed for future trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:28
verses.text: Numbers of other vegetables are the same and all over the earth reproduce by the roots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:29
verses.text: Nothing then is truer than that each plant produces its seed or contains some seminal virtue; this is what is meant by "after its kind".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:30
verses.text: So that the shoot of a reed does not produce an olive tree, but from a reed grows another reed, and from one sort of seed a plant of the same sort always germinates.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:31
verses.text: Thus, all which sprang from the earth, in its first bringing forth, is kept the same to our time, thanks to the constant reproduction of kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:32
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:33
verses.text: See how, at this short word, at this brief command, the cold and sterile earth travailed and hastened to bring forth its fruit, as it cast away its sad and dismal covering to clothe itself in a more brilliant robe, proud of its proper adornment and displaying the infinite variety of plants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:34
verses.text: I want creation to penetrate you with so much admiration that everywhere, wherever you may be, the least plant may bring to you the clear remembrance of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:35
verses.text: If you see the grass of the fields, think of human nature, and remember the comparison of the wise Isaiah.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:36
verses.text: "All flesh is grass, and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:37
verses.text: Truly the rapid flow of life, the short gratification and pleasure that an instant of happiness gives a man, all wonderfully suit the comparison of the prophet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:38
verses.text: To-day he is vigorous in body, fattened by luxury, and in the prime of life, with complexion fair like the flowers, strong and powerful and of irresistible energy; tomorrow and he will be an object of pity, withered by age or exhausted by sickness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:39
verses.text: Another shines in all the splendour of a brilliant fortune, and around him are a multitude of flatterers, an escort of false friends on the track of his good graces; a crowd of kinsfolk, but of no true kin; a swarm of servants who crowd after him to provide for his food and for all his needs; and in his comings and goings this innumerable suite, which he drags after him, excites the envy of all whom he meets.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:40
verses.text: To fortune may be added power in the State, honours bestowed by the imperial throne, the government of a province, or the command of armies; a herald who precedes him is crying in a loud voice; lictors right and left also fill his subjects with awe, blows, confiscations, banishments, imprisonments, and all the means by which he strikes intolerable terror into all whom he has to rule.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:41
verses.text: And what then? One night, a fever, a pleurisy, or an inflammation of the lungs, snatches away this man from the midst of men, stripped in a moment of all his stage accessories, and all this, his glory, is proved a mere dream.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:42
verses.text: Therefore the Prophet has compared human glory to the weakest flower.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:44
verses.text: Up to this point, the order in which plants shoot bears witness to their first arrangement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:45
verses.text: Every herb, every plant proceeds from a germ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:46
verses.text: If, like the couch-grass and the crocus, it throws out a shoot from its root and from this lower protuberance, it must always germinate and start outwards.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:47
verses.text: If it proceeds from a seed, there is still, by necessity, first a germ, then the sprout, then green foliage, and finally the fruit which ripens upon a stalk hitherto dry and thick.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:48
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:49
verses.text: When the seed falls into the earth, which contains the right combination of heat and moisture, it swells and becomes porous, and, grasping the surrounding earth, attracts to itself all that is suitable for it and that has affinity to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:50
verses.text: These particles of earth, however small they may be, as they fall and insinuate themselves into all the pores of the seed, broaden its bulk and make it send forth roots below, and shoot upwards, sending forth stalks no less numerous than the roots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:51
verses.text: As the germ is always growing warm, the moisture, pumped up through the roots, and helped by the attraction of heat, draws a proper amount of nourishment from the soil, and distributes it to the stem, to the bark, to the husk, to the seed itself and to the beards with which it is armed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:52
verses.text: It is owing to these successive accretions that each plant attains its natural development, as well corn as vegetables, herbs or brushwood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:53
verses.text: A single plant, a blade of grass is sufficient to occupy all your intelligence in the contemplation of the skill which produced it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:54
verses.text: Why is the wheat stalk better with joints? Are they not like fastenings, which help it to bear easily the weight of the ear, when it is swollen with fruit and bends towards the earth? Thus, whilst oats, which have no weight to bear at the top, are without these supports, nature has provided them for wheat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:55
verses.text: It has hidden the grain in a case, so that it may not be exposed to birds' pillage, and has furnished it with a rampart of barbs, which, like darts, protect it against the attacks of tiny creatures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:57
verses.text: What shall I say? What shall I leave unsaid? In the rich treasures of creation it is difficult to select what is most precious; the loss of what is omitted is too severe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:58
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass;" and instantly, with useful plants, appear noxious plants; with corn, hemlock; with the other nutritious plants, hellebore, monkshood, mandrake and the juice of the poppy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:59
verses.text: What then? Shall we show no gratitude for so many beneficial gifts, and reproach the Creator for those which may be harmful to our life? And shall we not reflect that all has not been created in view of the wants of our bellies? The nourishing plants, which are destined for our use, are close at hand, and known by all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:60
verses.text: But in creation nothing exists without a reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:61
verses.text: The blood of the bull is a poison: ought this animal then, whose strength is so serviceable to man, not to have been created, or, if created, to have been bloodless? But you have sense enough in yourself to keep you free from deadly things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:62
verses.text: What! Sheep and goats know how to turn away from what threatens their life, discerning danger by instinct alone: and you, who have reason and the art of medicine to supply what you need, and the experience of your forebears to tell you to avoid all that is dangerous, you tell me that you find it difficult to keep yourself from poisons! But not a single thing has been created without reason, not a single thing is useless.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:63
verses.text: One serves as food to some animal; medicine has found in another a relief for one of our maladies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:64
verses.text: Thus the starling eats hemlock, its constitution rendering it insusceptible to the action of the poison.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:65
verses.text: Thanks to the tenuity of the pores of its heart, the malignant juice is no sooner swallowed than it is digested, before its chill can attack the vital parts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:66
verses.text: The quail, thanks to its peculiar temperament, whereby it escapes the dangerous effects, feeds on hellebore.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:67
verses.text: There are even circumstances where poisons are useful to men; with mandrake doctors give us sleep; with opium they lull violent pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:68
verses.text: Hemlock has ere now been used to appease the rage of unruly diseases; and many times hellebore has taken away long standing disease.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:69
verses.text: These plants, then, instead of making you accuse the Creator, give you a new subject for gratitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:71
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:72
verses.text: What spontaneous provision is included in these words,—that which is present in the root, in the plant itself, and in the fruit, as well as that which our labour and husbandry add! God did not command the earth immediately to give forth seed and fruit, but to produce germs, to grow green, and to arrive at maturity in the seed; so that this first command teaches nature what she has to do in the course of ages.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:73
verses.text: But, they ask, is it true that the earth produces seed after his kind, when often, after having sown wheat, we gather black grain? This is not a change of kind, but an alteration, a disease of the grain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:74
verses.text: It has not ceased to be wheat; it is on account of having been burnt that it is black, as one can learn from its name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:75
verses.text: If a severe frost had burnt it, it would have had another colour and a different flavour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:76
verses.text: They even pretend that, if it could find suitable earth and moderate temperature, it might return to its first form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:77
verses.text: Thus, you find nothing in nature contrary to the divine command.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:78
verses.text: As to the darnel and all those bastard grains which mix themselves with the harvest, the tares of Scripture, far from being a variety of corn, have their own origin and their own kind; image of those who alter the doctrine of the Lord and, not being rightly instructed in the word, but, corrupted by the teaching of the evil one, mix themselves with the sound body of the Church to spread their pernicious errors secretly among purer souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:79
verses.text: The Lord thus compares the perfection of those who believe in Him to the growth of seed, "as if a man should cast seed into the ground; and should sleep and rise, night and day, and the seed should spring and grow up, he knoweth not how.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:80
verses.text: For the earth bringeth forth fruit of herself; first the blade, then the ear, after that the full corn in the ear".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:81
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth grass".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:82
verses.text: In a moment earth began by germination to obey the laws of the Creator, completed every stage of growth, and brought germs to perfection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:83
verses.text: The meadows were covered with deep grass, the fertile plains quivered with harvests, and the movement of the corn was like the waving of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:84
verses.text: Every plant, every herb, the smallest shrub, the least vegetable, arose from the earth in all its luxuriance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:85
verses.text: There was no failure in this first vegetation: no husbandman's inexperience, no inclemency of the weather, nothing could injure it; then the sentence of condemnation was not fettering the earth's fertility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:86
verses.text: All this was before the sin which condemned us to eat our bread by the sweat of our brow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:88
verses.text: "Let the earth," the Creator adds, "bring forth the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind, whose seed is in itself".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:89
verses.text: At this command every copse was thickly planted; all the trees, fir, cedar, cypress, pine, rose to their greatest height, the shrubs were straightway clothed with thick foliage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:90
verses.text: The plants called crown-plants, roses, myrtles, laurels, did not exist; in one moment they came into being, each one with its distinctive peculiarities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:91
verses.text: Most marked differences separated them from other plants, and each one was distinguished by a character of its own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:92
verses.text: But then the rose was without thorns; since then the thorn has been added to its beauty, to make us feel that sorrow is very near to pleasure, and to remind us of our sin, which condemned the earth to produce thorns and caltrops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:93
verses.text: But, they say, the earth has received the command to produce trees "yielding fruit whose seed was in itself," and we see many trees which have neither fruit, nor seed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:94
verses.text: What shall we reply? First, that only the more important trees are mentioned; and then, that a careful examination will show us that every tree has seed, or some property which takes the place of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:95
verses.text: The black poplar, the willow, the elm, the white poplar, all the trees of this family, do not produce any apparent fruit; however, an attentive observer finds seed in each of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:96
verses.text: This grain which is at the base of the leaf, and which those who busy themselves with inventing words call mischos, has the property of seed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:97
verses.text: And there are trees which reproduce by their branches, throwing out roots from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:98
verses.text: Perhaps we ought even to consider as seeds the saplings which spring from the roots of a tree: for cultivators tear them out to multiply the species.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:99
verses.text: But, we have already said, it is chiefly a question of the trees which contribute most to our life; which offer their various fruits to man and provide him with plentiful nourishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:100
verses.text: Such is the vine, which produces wine to make glad the heart of man; such is the olive tree, whose fruit brightens his face with oil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:101
verses.text: How many things in nature are combined in the same plant! In a vine, roots, green and flexible branches, which spread themselves far over the earth, buds, tendrils, bunches of sour grapes and ripe grapes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:102
verses.text: The sight of a vine, when observed by an intelligent eye, serves to remind you of your nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:103
verses.text: Without doubt you remember the parable where the Lord calls Himself a vine and His Father the husbandman, and every one of us who are grafted by faith into the Church the branches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:104
verses.text: He invites us to produce fruits in abundance, for fear lest our sterility should condemn us to the fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:105
verses.text: He constantly compares our souls to vines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:106
verses.text: "My well beloved," says He, "hath a vineyard in a very fruitfull hill," and elsewhere, I have "planted a vineyard and hedged it round about".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:107
verses.text: Evidently He calls human souls His vine, those souls whom He has surrounded with the authority of His precepts and a guard of angels.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:108
verses.text: "The angel of the Lord encampeth round about them that fear him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:109
verses.text: And further: He has planted for us, so to say, props, in establishing in His Church apostles, prophets, teachers; and raising our thoughts by the example of the blessed in olden times, He has not allowed them to drag on the earth and be crushed under foot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:110
verses.text: He wishes that the claspings of love, like the tendrils of the vine, should attach us to our neighbours and make us rest on them, so that, in our continual aspirations towards heaven, we may imitate these vines, which raise themselves to the tops of the tallest trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:111
