verses.text: He also asks us to allow ourselves to be dug about; and that is what the soul does when it disembarrasses itself from the cares of the world, which are a weight on our hearts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:112
verses.text: He, then, who is freed from carnal affections and from the love of riches, and, far from being dazzled by them, disdains and despises this miserable vain glory, is, so to say, dug about and at length breathes, free from the useless weight of earthly thoughts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:113
verses.text: Nor must we, in the spirit of the parable, put forth too much wood, that is to say, live with ostentation, and gain the applause of the world; we must bring forth fruits, keeping the proof of our works for the husbandman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:114
verses.text: Be "like a green olive tree in the house of God," never destitute of hope, but decked through faith with the bloom of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:115
verses.text: Thus you will resemble the eternal verdure of this plant and will rival it in fruitfulness, if each day sees you giving abundantly in alms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:117
verses.text: But let us return to the examination of the ingenious contrivances of creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:118
verses.text: How many trees then arose, some to give us their fruits, others to roof our houses, others to build our ships, others to feed our fires! What a variety in the disposition of their several parts! And yet, how difficult is it to find the distinctive property of each of them, and to grasp the difference which separates them from other species.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:119
verses.text: Some strike deep roots, others do not; some shoot straight up and have only one stem, others appear to love the earth and, from their root upwards, divide into several shoots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:120
verses.text: Those whose long branches stretch up afar into the air, have also deep roots which spread within a large circumference, a true foundation placed by nature to support the weight of the tree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:121
verses.text: What variety there is in bark! Some plants have smooth bark, others rough, some have only one layer, others several.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:122
verses.text: What a marvellous thing! You may find in the youth and age of plants resemblances to those of man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:123
verses.text: Young and vigorous, their bark is distended; when they grow old, it is rough and wrinkled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:124
verses.text: Cut one, it sends forth new buds; the other remains henceforward sterile and as if struck with a mortal wound.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:125
verses.text: But further, it has been observed that pines, cut down, or even submitted to the action of fire, are changed into a forest of oaks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:126
verses.text: We know besides that the industry of agriculturists remedies the natural defects of certain trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:127
verses.text: Thus the sharp pomegranate and bitter almonds, if the trunk of the tree is pierced near the root to introduce into the middle of the pith a fat plug of pine, lose the acidity of their juice, and become delicious fruits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:128
verses.text: Let not the sinner then despair of himself, when he thinks, if agriculture can change the juices of plants, the efforts of the soul to arrive at virtue, can certainly triumph over all infirmities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:129
verses.text: Now there is such a variety of fruits in fruit trees that it is beyond all expression; a variety not only in the fruits of trees of different families, but even in those of the same species, if it be true, as gardeners say, that the sex of a tree influences the character of its fruits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:130
verses.text: They distinguish male from female in palms; sometimes we see those which they call female lower their branches, as though with passionate desire, and invite the embraces of the male.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:131
verses.text: Then, those who take care of these plants shake over these palms the fertilizing dust from the male palm-tree, the psen as they call it: the tree appears to share the pleasures of enjoyment; then it raises its branches, and its foliage resumes its usual form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:132
verses.text: The same is said of the fig tree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:133
verses.text: Some plant wild fig trees near cultivated fig trees, and there are others who, to remedy the weakness of the productive fig tree of our gardens, attach to the branches unripe figs and so retain the fruit which had already begun to drop and to be lost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:134
verses.text: What lesson does nature here give us? That we must often borrow, even from those who are strangers to the faith, a certain vigour to show forth good works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:135
verses.text: If you see outside the Church, in pagan life, or in the midst of a pernicious heresy, the example of virtue and fidelity to moral laws, redouble your efforts to resemble the productive fig tree, who by the side of the wild fig tree, gains strength, prevents the fruit from being shed, and nourishes it with more care.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:137
verses.text: Plants reproduce themselves in so many different ways, that we can only touch upon the chief among them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:138
verses.text: As to fruits themselves, who could review their varieties, their forms, their colours, the peculiar flavour, and the use of each of them? Why do some fruits ripen when exposed bare to the rays of the sun, while others fill out while encased in shells? Trees of which the fruit is tender have, like the fig tree, a thick shade of leaves; those, on the contrary, of which the fruits are stouter, like the nut, are only covered by a light shade.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:139
verses.text: The delicacy of the first requires more care; if the latter had a thicker case, the shade of the leaves would be harmful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:140
verses.text: Why is the vine leaf serrated, if not that the bunches of grapes may at the same time resist the injuries of the air and receive through the openings all the rays of the sun? Nothing has been done without motive, nothing by chance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:141
verses.text: All shows ineffable wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:142
verses.text: What discourse can touch all? Can the human mind make an exact review, remark every distinctive property, exhibit all the differences, unveil with certainty so many mysterious causes? The same water, pumped up through the root, nourishes in a different way the root itself, the bark of the trunk, the wood and the pith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:143
verses.text: It becomes leaf, it distributes itself among the branches and twigs and makes the fruits swell—it gives to the plant its gum and its sap.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:144
verses.text: Who will explain to us the difference between all these? There is a difference between the gum of the mastich and the juice of the balsam, a difference between that which distils in Egypt and Libya from the fennel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:145
verses.text: Amber is, they say, the crystallized sap of plants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:146
verses.text: And for a proof, see the bits of straws and little insects which have been caught in the sap while still liquid and imprisoned there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:147
verses.text: In one word, no one without long experience could find terms to express the virtue of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:148
verses.text: How, again, does this water become wine in the vine, and oil in the olive tree? Yet what is marvellous is, not to see it become sweet in one fruit, fat and unctuous in another, but to see in sweet fruits an inexpressible variety of flavour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:149
verses.text: There is one sweetness of the grape, another of the apple, another of the fig, another of the date.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:150
verses.text: I shall willingly give you the gratification of continuing this research.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:151
verses.text: How is it that this same water has sometimes a sweet taste, softened by its remaining in certain plants, and at other times stings the palate because it has become acid by passing through others? How is it, again, that it attains extreme bitterness, and makes the mouth rough when it is found in wormwood and in scammony? That it has in acorns and dogwood a sharp and rough flavour? That in the turpentine tree and the walnut tree it is changed into a soft and oily matter?  9.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:152
verses.text: But what need is there to continue, when in the same fig tree we have the most opposite flavours, as bitter in the sap as it is sweet in the fruit? And in the vine, is it not as sweet in the grapes as it is astringent in the branches? And what a variety of colour! Look how in a meadow this same water becomes red in one flower, purple in another, blue in this one, white in that.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:153
verses.text: And this diversity of colours, is it to be compared to that of scents? But I perceive that an insatiable curiosity is drawing out my discourse beyond its limits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:154
verses.text: If I do not stop and recall it to the law of creation, day will fail me whilst making you see great wisdom in small things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:155
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the fruit tree yielding fruit".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:156
verses.text: Immediately the tops of the mountains were covered with foliage: paradises were artfully laid out, and an infinitude of plants embellished the banks of the rivers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:157
verses.text: Some were for the adornment of man's table; some to nourish animals with their fruits and their leaves; some to provide medicinal help by giving us their sap, their juice, their chips, their bark or their fruit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:158
verses.text: In a word, the experience of ages, profiting from every chance, has not been able to discover anything useful, which the penetrating foresight of the Creator did not first perceive and call into existence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:159
verses.text: Therefore, when you see the trees in our gardens, or those of the forest, those which love the water or the land, those which bear flowers, or those which do not flower, I should like to see you recognising grandeur even in small objects, adding incessantly to your admiration of, and redoubling your love for the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:160
verses.text: Ask yourself why He has made some trees evergreen and others deciduous; why, among the first, some lose their leaves, and others always keep them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:161
verses.text: Thus the olive and the pine shed their leaves, although they renew them insensibly and never appear to be despoiled of their verdure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:162
verses.text: The palm tree, on the contrary, from its birth to its death, is always adorned with the same foliage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:163
verses.text: Think again of the double life of the tamarisk; it is an aquatic plant, and yet it covers the desert.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:164
verses.text: Thus, Jeremiah compares it to the worst of characters—the double character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:166
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:167
verses.text: This short command was in a moment a vast nature, an elaborate system.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:168
verses.text: Swifter than thought it produced the countless qualities of plants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:169
verses.text: It is this command which, still at this day, is imposed on the earth, and in the course of each year displays all the strength of its power to produce herbs, seeds and trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:170
verses.text: Like tops, which after the first impulse, continue their evolutions, turning upon themselves when once fixed in their centre; thus nature, receiving the impulse of this first command, follows without interruption the course of ages, until the consummation of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 5:171
verses.text: Let us all hasten to attain to it, full of fruit and of good works; and thus, planted in the house of the Lord we shall flourish in the court of our God, in our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom be glory and power for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:2
verses.text: The creation of luminous bodies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:4
verses.text: At the shows in the circus the spectator must join in the efforts of the athletes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:5
verses.text: This the laws of the show indicate, for they prescribe that all should have the head uncovered when present at the stadium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:6
verses.text: The object of this, in my opinion, is that each one there should not only be a spectator of the athletes, but be, in a certain measure, a true athlete himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:7
verses.text: Thus, to investigate the great and prodigious show of creation, to understand supreme and ineffable wisdom, you must bring personal light for the contemplation of the wonders which I spread before your eyes, and help me, according to your power, in this struggle, where you are not so much judges as fellow combatants, for fear lest the truth might escape you, and lest my error might turn to your common prejudice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:8
verses.text: Why these words? It is because we propose to study the world as a whole, and to consider the universe, not by the light of worldly wisdom, but by that with which God wills to enlighten His servant, when He speaks to him in person and without enigmas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:9
verses.text: It is because it is absolutely necessary that all lovers of great and grand shows should bring a mind well prepared to study them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:10
verses.text: If sometimes, on a bright night, whilst gazing with watchful eyes on the inexpressible beauty of the stars, you have thought of the Creator of all things; if you have asked yourself who it is that has dotted heaven with such flowers, and why visible things are even more useful than beautiful; if sometimes, in the day, you have studied the marvels of light, if you have raised yourself by visible things to the invisible Being, then you are a well prepared auditor, and you can take your place in this august and blessed amphitheatre.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:11
verses.text: Come in the same way that any one not knowing a town is taken by the hand and led through it; thus I am going to lead you, like strangers, through the mysterious marvels of this great city of the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:12
verses.text: Our first country was in this great city, whence the murderous daemon whose enticements seduced man to slavery expelled us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:13
verses.text: There you will see man's first origin and his immediate seizure by death, brought forth by sin, the first born of the evil spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:14
verses.text: You will know that you are formed of earth, but the work of God's hands; much weaker than the brute, but ordained to command beings without reason and soul; inferior as regards natural advantages, but, thanks to the privilege of reason, capable of raising yourself to heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:15
verses.text: If we are penetrated by these truths, we shall know ourselves, we shall know God, we shall adore our Creator, we shall serve our Master, we shall glorify our Father, we shall love our Sustainer, we shall bless our Benefactor, we shall not cease to honour the Prince of present and future life, Who, by the riches that He showers upon us in this world, makes us believe in His promises and uses present good things to strengthen our expectation of the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:16
verses.text: Truly, if such are the good things of time, what will be those of eternity? If such is the beauty of visible things, what shall we think of invisible things? If the grandeur of heaven exceeds the measure of human intelligence, what mind shall be able to trace the nature of the everlasting? If the sun, subject to corruption, is so beautiful, so grand, so rapid in its movement, so invariable in its course; if its grandeur is in such perfect harmony with and due proportion to the universe: if, by the beauty of its nature, it shines like a brilliant eye in the middle of creation; if finally, one cannot tire of contemplating it, what will be the beauty of the Sun of Righteousness? If the blind man suffers from not seeing the material sun, what a deprivation is it for the sinner not to enjoy the true light!  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:17
verses.text: "And God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth, and to divide the day from the night".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:18
verses.text: Heaven and earth were the first; after them was created light; the day had been distinguished from the night, then had appeared the firmament and the dry element.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:19
verses.text: The water had been gathered into the reservoir assigned to it, the earth displayed its productions, it had caused many kinds of herbs to germinate and it was adorned with all kinds of plants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:20
verses.text: However, the sun and the moon did not yet exist, in order that those who live in ignorance of God may not consider the sun as the origin and the father of light, or as the maker of all that grows out of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:21
verses.text: That is why there was a fourth day, and then God said: "Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:22
verses.text: When once you have learnt Who spoke, think immediately of the hearer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:23
verses.text: God said, "Let there be lights…and God made two great lights".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:24
verses.text: Who spoke? and Who made? Do you not see a double person? Everywhere, in mystic language, history is sown with the dogmas of theology.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:25
verses.text: The motive follows which caused the lights to be created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:26
verses.text: It was to illuminate the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:27
verses.text: Already light was created; why therefore say that the sun was created to give light? And, first, do not laugh at the strangeness of this expression.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:28
verses.text: We do not follow your nicety about words, and we trouble ourselves but little to give them a harmonious turn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:29
verses.text: Our writers do not amuse themselves by polishing their periods, and everywhere we prefer clearness of words to sonorous expressions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:30
verses.text: See then if by this expression "to light up," the sacred writer sufficiently made his thought understood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:31
verses.text: He has put "to give light" instead of "illumination".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:32
verses.text: Now there is nothing here contradictory to what has been said of light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:33
verses.text: Then the actual nature of light was produced: now the sun's body is constructed to be a vehicle for that original light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:34
verses.text: A lamp is not fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:35
verses.text: Fire has the property of illuminating, and we have invented the lamp to light us in darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:36
verses.text: In the same way, the luminous bodies have been fashioned as a vehicle for that pure, clear, and immaterial light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:37
verses.text: The Apostle speaks to us of certain lights which shine in the world without being confounded with the true light of the world, the possession of which made the saints luminaries of the souls which they instructed and drew from the darkness of ignorance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:38
verses.text: This is why the Creator of all things, made the sun in addition to that glorious light, and placed it shining in the heavens.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:40
verses.text: And let no one suppose it to be a thing incredible that the brightness of the light is one thing, and the body which is its material vehicle is another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:41
verses.text: First, in all composite things, we distinguish substance susceptible of quality, and the quality which it receives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:42
verses.text: The nature of whiteness is one thing, another is that of the body which is whitened; thus the natures differ which we have just seen reunited by the power of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:43
verses.text: And do not tell me that it is impossible to separate them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:44
verses.text: Even I do not pretend to be able to separate light from the body of the sun; but I maintain that that which we separate in thought, may be separated in reality by the Creator of nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:45
verses.text: You cannot, moreover, separate the brightness of fire from the virtue of burning which it possesses; but God, who wished to attract His servant by a wonderful sight, set a fire in the burning bush, which displayed all the brilliancy of flame while its devouring property was dormant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:46
verses.text: It is that which the Psalmist affirms in saying "The voice of the Lord divideth the flames of fire".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:47
verses.text: Thus, in the requital which awaits us after this life, a mysterious voice seems to tell us that the double nature of fire will be divided; the just will enjoy its light, and the torment of its heat will be the torture of the wicked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:48
verses.text: In the revolutions of the moon we find anew proof of what we have advanced.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:49
verses.text: When it stops and grows less it does not consume itself in all its body, but in the measure that it deposits or absorbs the light which surrounds it, it presents to us the image of its decrease or of its increase.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:50
verses.text: If we wish an evident proof that the moon does not consume its body when at rest, we have only to open our eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:51
verses.text: If you look at it in a cloudless and clear sky, you observe, when it has taken the complete form of a crescent, that the part, which is dark and not lighted up, describes a circle equal to that which the full moon forms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:52
verses.text: Thus the eye can take in the whole circle, if it adds to the illuminated part this obscure and dark curve.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:53
verses.text: And do not tell me that the light of the moon is borrowed, diminishing or increasing in proportion as it approaches or recedes from the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:54
verses.text: That is not now the object of our research; we only wish to prove that its body differs from the light which makes it shine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:55
verses.text: I wish you to have the same idea of the sun; except however that the one, after having once received light and having mixed it with its substance, does not lay it down again, whilst the other, turn by turn, putting off and reclothing itself again with light, proves by that which takes place in itself what we have said of the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:56
verses.text: The sun and moon thus received the command to divide the day from the night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:57
verses.text: God had already separated light from darkness; then He placed their natures in opposition, so that they could not mingle, and that there could never be anything in common between darkness and light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:58
verses.text: You see what a shadow is during the day; that is precisely the nature of darkness during the night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:59
verses.text: If, at the appearance of a light, the shadow always falls on the opposite side; if in the morning it extends towards the setting sun; if in the evening it inclines towards the rising sun, and at mid-day turns towards the north; night retires into the regions opposed to the rays of the sun, since it is by nature only the shadow of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:60
verses.text: Because, in the same way that, during the day, shadow is produced by a body which intercepts the light, night comes naturally when the air which surrounds the earth is in shadow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:61
verses.text: And this is precisely what Scripture says, "God divided the light from the darkness".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:62
verses.text: Thus darkness fled at the approach of light, the two being at their first creation divided by a natural antipathy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:63
verses.text: Now God commanded the sun to measure the day, and the moon, whenever she rounds her disc, to rule the night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:64
verses.text: For then these two luminaries are almost diametrically opposed; when the sun rises, the full moon disappears from the horizon, to re-appear in the east at the moment the sun sets.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:65
verses.text: It matters little to our subject if in other phases the light of the moon does not correspond exactly with night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:66
verses.text: It is none the less true, that when at its perfection it makes the stars to turn pale and lightens up the earth with the splendour of its light, it reigns over the night, and in concert with the sun divides the duration of it in equal parts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:68
verses.text: "And let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:69
verses.text: The signs which the luminaries give are necessary to human life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:70
verses.text: In fact what useful observations will long experience make us discover, if we ask without undue curiosity! What signs of rain, of drought, or of the rising of the wind, partial or general, violent or moderate! Our Lord indicates to us one of the signs given by the sun when He says, "It will be foul weather to-day; for the sky is red and lowering".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:71
verses.text: In fact, when the sun rises through a fog, its rays are darkened, but the disc appears burning like a coal and of a bloody red colour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:72
verses.text: It is the thickness of the air which causes this appearance; as the rays of the sun do not disperse such amassed and condensed air, it cannot certainly be retained by the waves of vapour which exhale from the earth, and it will cause from superabundance of moisture a storm in the countries over which it accumulates.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:73
verses.text: In the same way, when the moon is surrounded with moisture, or when the sun is encircled with what is called a halo, it is the sign of heavy rain or of a violent storm; again, in the same way, if mock suns accompany the sun in its course they foretell certain celestial phenomena.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:74
verses.text: Finally, those straight lines, like the colours of the rainbow, which are seen on the clouds, announce rain, extraordinary tempests, or, in one word, a complete change in the weather.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:75
verses.text: Those who devote themselves to the observation of these bodies find signs in the different phases of the moon, as if the air, by which the earth is enveloped, were obliged to vary to correspond with its change of form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:76
verses.text: Towards the third day of the new moon, if it is sharp and clear, it is a sign of fixed fine weather.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:77
verses.text: If its horns appear thick and reddish it threatens us either with heavy rain or with a gale from the South.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:78
verses.text: Who does not know how useful are these signs in life? Thanks to them, the sailor keeps back his vessel in the harbour, foreseeing the perils with which the winds threaten him, and the traveller beforehand takes shelter from harm, waiting until the weather has become fairer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:79
verses.text: Thanks to them, husbandmen, busy with sowing seed or cultivating plants, are able to know which seasons are favourable to their labours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:80
verses.text: Further, the Lord has announced to us that at the dissolution of the universe, signs will appear in the sun, in the moon and in the stars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:81
verses.text: The sun shall be turned into blood and the moon shall not give her light, signs of the consummation of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:83
verses.text: But those who overstep the borders, making the words of Scripture their apology for the art of casting nativities, pretend that our lives depend upon the motion of the heavenly bodies, and that thus the Chaldaeans read in the planets that which will happen to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:84
verses.text: By these very simple words "let them be for signs," they understand neither the variations of the weather, nor the change of seasons; they only see in them, at the will of their imagination, the distribution of human destinies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:85
verses.text: What do they say in reality? When the planets cross in the signs of the Zodiac, certain figures formed by their meeting give birth to certain destinies, and others produce different destinies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:86
verses.text: Perhaps for clearness sake it is not useless to enter into more detail about this vain science.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:87
verses.text: I will say nothing of my own to refute them; I will use their words, bringing a remedy for the infected, and for others a preservative from falling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:88
verses.text: The inventors of astrology seeing that in the extent of time many signs escaped them, divided it and enclosed each part in narrow limits, as if in the least and shortest interval, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, to speak with the Apostle, the greatest difference should be found between one birth and another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:89
verses.text: Such an one is born in this moment; he will be a prince over cities and will govern the people, in the fulness of riches and power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:90
verses.text: Another is born the instant after; he will be poor, miserable, and will wander daily from door to door begging his bread.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:91
verses.text: Consequently they divide the Zodiac into twelve parts, and, as the sun takes thirty days to traverse each of the twelve divisions of this unerring circle, they divide them into thirty more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:92
verses.text: Each of them forms sixty new ones, and these last are again divided into sixty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:93
verses.text: Let us see then if, in determining the birth of an infant, it will be possible to observe this rigorous division of time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:94
verses.text: The child is born.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:95
verses.text: The nurse ascertains the sex; then she awaits the wail which is a sign of its life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:96
verses.text: Until then how many moments have passed do you think? The nurse announces the birth of the child to the Chaldaean: how many minutes would you count before she opens her mouth, especially if he who records the hour is outside the women's apartments? And we know that he who consults the dial, ought, whether by day or by night, to mark the hour with the most precise exactitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:97
verses.text: What a swarm of seconds passes during this time! For the planet of nativity ought to be found, not only in one of the twelve divisions of the Zodiac, and even in one of its first subdivisions, but again in one of the sixtieth parts which divide this last, and even, to arrive at the exact truth, in one of the sixtieth subdivisions that this contains in its turn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:98
verses.text: And to obtain such minute knowledge, so impossible to grasp from this moment, each planet must be questioned to find its position as regards the signs of the Zodiac and the figures that the planets form at the moment of the child's birth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:99
verses.text: Thus, if it is impossible to find exactly the hour of birth, and if the least change can upset all, then both those who give themselves up to this imaginary science and those who listen to them open-mouthed, as if they could learn from them the future, are supremely ridiculous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:101
verses.text: But what effects are produced? Such an one will have curly hair and bright eyes, because he is born under the Ram; such is the appearance of a ram.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:102
verses.text: He will have noble feelings; because the Ram is born to command.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:103
verses.text: He will be liberal and fertile in resources, because this animal gets rid of its fleece without trouble, and nature immediately hastens to reclothe it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:104
verses.text: Another is born under the Bull: he will be enured to hardship and of a slavish character, because the bull bows under the yoke.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:105
verses.text: Another is born under the Scorpion; like to this venomous reptile he will be a striker.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:106
verses.text: He who is born under the Balance will be just, thanks to the justness of our balances.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:107
verses.text: Is not this the height of folly? This Ram, from whence you draw the nativity of man, is the twelfth part of the heaven, and in entering into it the sun reaches the spring.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:108
verses.text: The Balance and the Bull are likewise twelfth parts of the Zodiac.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:109
verses.text: How can you see there the principal causes which influence the life of man? And why do you take animals to characterize the manners of men who enter this world? He who is born under the Ram will be liberal, not because this part of heaven gives this characteristic, but because such is the nature of the beast.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:110
verses.text: Why then should we frighten ourselves by the names of these stars and undertake to persuade ourselves with these bleatings? If heaven has different characteristics derived from these animals, it is then itself subject to external influences since its causes depend on the brutes who graze in our fields.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:111
verses.text: A ridiculous assertion; but how much more ridiculous the pretence of arriving at the influence on each other of things which have not the least connexion! This pretended science is a true spider's web; if a gnat or a fly, or some insect equally feeble falls into it it is held entangled; if a stronger animal approaches, it passes through without trouble, carrying the weak tissue away with it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:113
verses.text: They do not, however, stop here; even our acts, where each one feels his will ruling, I mean, the practice of virtue or of vice, depend, according to them, on the influence of celestial bodies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:114
verses.text: It would be ridiculous seriously to refute such an error, but, as it holds a great many in its nets, perhaps it is better not to pass it over in silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:115
verses.text: I would first ask them if the figures which the stars describe do not change a thousand times a day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:116
verses.text: In the perpetual motion of planets, some meet in a more rapid course, others make slower revolutions, and often in an hour we see them look at each other and then hide themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:117
verses.text: Now, at the hour of birth, it is very important whether one is looked upon by a beneficent star or by an evil one, to speak their language.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:118
verses.text: Often then the astrologers do not seize the moment when a good star shows itself, and, on account of having let this fugitive moment escape, they enrol the newborn under the influence of a bad genius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:119
verses.text: I am compelled to use their own words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:120
verses.text: What madness! But, above all, what impiety! For the evil stars throw the blame of their wickedness upon Him Who made them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:121
verses.text: If evil is inherent in their nature, the Creator is the author of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:122
verses.text: If they make it themselves, they are animals endowed with the power of choice, whose acts will be free and voluntary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:123
verses.text: Is it not the height of folly to tell these lies about beings without souls? Again, what a want of sense does it show to distribute good and evil without regard to personal merit; to say that a star is beneficent because it occupies a certain place; that it becomes evil, because it is viewed by another star; and that if it moves ever so little from this figure it loses its malign influence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:124
verses.text: But let us pass on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:125
verses.text: If, at every instant of duration, the stars vary their figures, then in these thousand changes, many times a day, there ought to be reproduced the configuration of royal births.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:126
verses.text: Why then does not every day see the birth of a king? Why is there a succession on the throne from father to son? Without doubt there has never been a king who has taken measures to have his son born under the star of royalty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:127
verses.text: For what man possesses such a power? How then did Uzziah beget Jotham, Jotham Ahaz, Ahaz Hezekiah? And by what chance did the birth of none of them happen in an hour of slavery? If the origin of our virtues and of our vices is not in ourselves, but is the fatal consequence of our birth, it is useless for legislators to prescribe for us what we ought to do, and what we ought to avoid; it is useless for judges to honour virtue and to punish vice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:128
verses.text: The guilt is not in the robber, not in the assassin: it was willed for him; it was impossible for him to hold back his hand, urged to evil by inevitable necessity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:129
verses.text: Those who laboriously cultivate the arts are the maddest of men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:130
verses.text: The labourer will make an abundant harvest without sowing seed and without sharpening his sickle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:131
verses.text: Whether he wishes it or not, the merchant will make his fortune, and will be flooded with riches by fate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:132
verses.text: As for us Christians, we shall see our great hopes vanish, since from the moment that man does not act with freedom, there is neither reward for justice, nor punishment for sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:133
verses.text: Under the reign of necessity and of fatality there is no place for merit, the first condition of all righteous judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:134
verses.text: But let us stop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:135
verses.text: You who are sound in yourselves have no need to hear more, and time does not allow us to make attacks without limit against these unhappy men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:137
verses.text: Let us return to the words which follow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:138
verses.text: "Let them be for signs and for seasons and for days and years".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:139
verses.text: We have spoken about signs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:140
verses.text: By times, we understand the succession of seasons, winter, spring, summer and autumn, which we see follow each other in so regular a course, thanks to the regularity of the movement of the luminaries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:141
verses.text: It is winter when the sun sojourns in the south and produces in abundance the shades of night in our region.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:142
verses.text: The air spread over the earth is chilly, and the damp exhalations, which gather over our heads, give rise to rains, to frosts, to innumerable flakes of snow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:143
verses.text: When, returning from the southern regions, the sun is in the middle of the heavens and divides day and night into equal parts, the more it sojourns above the earth the more it brings back a mild temperature to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:144
verses.text: Then comes spring, which makes all the plants germinate, and gives to the greater part of the trees their new life, and, by successive generation, perpetuates all the land and water animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:145
verses.text: From thence the sun, returning to the summer solstice, in the direction of the North, gives us the longest days.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:146
verses.text: And, as it travels farther in the air, it burns that which is over our heads, dries up the earth, ripens the grains and hastens the maturity of the fruits of the trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:147
verses.text: At the epoch of its greatest heat, the shadows which the sun makes at mid-day are short, because it shines from above, from the air over our heads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:148
verses.text: Thus the longest days are those when the shadows are shortest, in the same way that the shortest days are those when the shadows are longest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:149
verses.text: It is this which happens to all of us "Hetero-skii" (shadowed-on-one-side) who inhabit the northern regions of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:150
verses.text: But there are people who, two days in the year, are completely without shade at mid-day, because the sun, being perpendicularly over their heads, lights them so equally from all sides, that it could through a narrow opening shine at the bottom of a well.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:151
verses.text: Thus there are some who call them "askii" (shadowless).

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:152
verses.text: For those who live beyond the land of spices see their shadow now on one side, now on another, the only inhabitants of this land of which the shade falls at mid-day; thus they are given the name of "amphiskii," (shadowed-on-both-sides ).

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:153
verses.text: All these phenomena happen whilst the sun is passing into northern regions: they give us an idea of the heat thrown on the air, by the rays of the sun and of the effects that they produce.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:154
verses.text: Next we pass to autumn, which breaks up the excessive heat, lessening the warmth little by little, and by a moderate temperature brings us back without suffering to winter, to the time when the sun returns from the northern regions to the southern.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:155
verses.text: It is thus that seasons, following the course of the sun, succeed each other to rule our life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:156
verses.text: "Let them be for days" says Scripture, not to produce them but to rule them; because day and night are older than the creation of the luminaries and it is this that the psalm declares to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:157
verses.text: "The sun to rule by day…the moon and stars to rule by night".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:158
verses.text: How does the sun rule by day? Because carrying everywhere light with it, it is no sooner risen above the horizon than it drives away darkness and brings us day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:159
verses.text: Thus we might, without self deception, define day as air lighted by the sun, or as the space of time that the sun passes in our hemisphere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:160
verses.text: The functions of the sun and moon serve further to mark years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:161
verses.text: The moon, after having twelve times run her course, forms a year which sometimes needs an intercalary month to make it exactly agree with the seasons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:162
verses.text: Such was formerly the year of the Hebrews and of the early Greeks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:163
verses.text: As to the solar year, it is the time that the sun, having started from a certain sign, takes to return to it in its normal progress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:165
verses.text: "And God made two great lights".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:166
verses.text: The word "great," if, for example we say it of the heaven of the earth or of the sea, may have an absolute sense; but ordinarily it has only a relative meaning, as a great horse, or a great ox.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:167
verses.text: It is not that these animals are of an immoderate size, but that in comparison with their like they deserve the title of great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:168
verses.text: What idea shall we ourselves form here of greatness? Shall it be the idea that we have of it in the ant and in all the little creatures of nature, which we call great in comparison with those like themselves, and to show their superiority over them? Or shall we predicate greatness of the luminaries, as of the natural greatness inherent in them? As for me, I think so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:169
verses.text: If the sun and moon are great, it is not in comparison with the smaller stars, but because they have such a circumference that the splendour which they diffuse lights up the heavens and the air, embracing at the same time earth and sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:170
verses.text: In whatever part of heaven they may be, whether rising, or setting, or in mid heaven, they appear always the same in the eyes of men, a manifest proof of their prodigious size.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:171
verses.text: For the whole extent of heaven cannot make them appear greater in one place and smaller in another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:172
verses.text: Objects which we see afar off appear dwarfed to our eyes, and in measure as they approach us we can form a juster idea of their size.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:173
verses.text: But there is no one who can be nearer or more distant from the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:174
verses.text: All the inhabitants of the earth see it at the same distance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:175
verses.text: Indians and Britons see it of the same size.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:176
verses.text: The people of the East do not see it decrease in magnitude when it sets; those of the West do not find it smaller when it rises.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:177
verses.text: If it is in the middle of the heavens it does not vary in either aspect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:178
verses.text: Do not be deceived by mere appearance, and because it looks a cubit's breadth, imagine it to be no bigger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:179
verses.text: At a very great distance objects always lose size in our eyes; sight, not being able to clear the intermediary space, is as it were exhausted in the middle of its course, and only a small part of it reaches the visible object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:180
verses.text: Our power of sight is small and makes all we see seem small, affecting what it sees by its own condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:181
verses.text: Thus, then, if sight is mistaken its testimony is fallible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:182
verses.text: Recall your own impressions and you will find in yourself the proof of my words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:183
verses.text: If you have ever from the top of a high mountain looked at a large and level plain, how big did the yokes of oxen appear to you? How big were the ploughmen themselves? Did they not look like ants? If from the top of a commanding rock, looking over the wide sea, you cast your eyes over the vast extent how big did the greatest islands appear to you? How large did one of those barks of great tonnage, which unfurl their white sails to the blue sea, appear to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:184
verses.text: Did it not look smaller than a dove? It is because sight, as I have just told you, loses itself in the air, becomes weak and cannot seize with exactness the object which it sees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:185
verses.text: And further: your sight shows you high mountains intersected by valleys as rounded and smooth, because it reaches only to the salient parts, and is not able, on account of its weakness, to penetrate into the valleys which separate them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:186
verses.text: It does not even preserve the form of objects, and thinks that all square towers are round.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:187
verses.text: Thus all proves that at a great distance sight only presents to us obscure and confused objects.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:188
verses.text: The luminary is then great, according to the witness of Scripture, and infinitely greater than it appears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:190
verses.text: See again another evident proof of its greatness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:191
verses.text: Although the heaven may be full of stars without number, the light contributed by them all could not disperse the gloom of night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:192
verses.text: The sun alone, from the time that it appeared on the horizon, while it was still expected and had not yet risen completely above the earth, dispersed the darkness, outshone the stars, dissolved and diffused the air, which was hitherto thick and condensed over our heads, and produced thus the morning breeze and the dew which in fine weather streams over the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:193
verses.text: Could the earth with such a wide extent be lighted up entirely in one moment if an immense disc were not pouring forth its light over it? Recognise here the wisdom of the Artificer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:194
verses.text: See how He made the heat of the sun proportionate to this distance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:195
verses.text: Its heat is so regulated that it neither consumes the earth by excess, nor lets it grow cold and sterile by defect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:196
verses.text: To all this the properties of the moon are near akin; she, too, has an immense body, whose splendour only yields to that of the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:197
verses.text: Our eyes, however, do not always see her in her full size.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:198
verses.text: Now she presents a perfectly rounded disc, now when diminished and lessened she shows a deficiency on one side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:199
verses.text: When waxing she is shadowed on one side, and when she is waning another side is hidden.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:200
verses.text: Now it is not without a secret reason of the divine Maker of the universe, that the moon appears from time to time under such different forms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:201
verses.text: It presents a striking example of our nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:202
verses.text: Nothing is stable in man; here from nothingness he raises himself to perfection; there after having hasted to put forth his strength to attain his full greatness he suddenly is subject to gradual deterioration, and is destroyed by diminution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:203
verses.text: Thus, the sight of the moon, making us think of the rapid vicissitudes of human things, ought to teach us not to pride ourselves on the good things of this life, and not to glory in our power, not to be carried away by uncertain riches, to despise our flesh which is subject to change, and to take care of the soul, for its good is unmoved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:204
verses.text: If you cannot behold without sadness the moon losing its splendour by gradual and imperceptible decrease, how much more distressed should you be at the sight of a soul, who, after having possessed virtue, loses its beauty by neglect, and does not remain constant to its affections, but is agitated and constantly changes because its purposes are unstable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:205
verses.text: What Scripture says is very true, "As for a fool he changeth as the moon".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:206
verses.text: I believe also that the variations of the moon do not take place without exerting great influence upon the organization of animals and of all living things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:207
verses.text: This is because bodies are differently disposed at its waxing and waning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:208
verses.text: When she wanes they lose their density and become void.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:209
verses.text: When she waxes and is approaching her fulness they appear to fill themselves at the same time with her, thanks to an imperceptible moisture that she emits mixed with heat, which penetrates everywhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:210
verses.text: For proof, see how those who sleep under the moon feel abundant moisture filling their heads; see how fresh meat is quickly turned under the action of the moon; see the brain of animals, the moistest part of marine animals, the pith of trees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:211
verses.text: Evidently the moon must be, as Scripture says, of enormous size and power to make all nature thus participate in her changes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:213
verses.text: On its variations depends also the condition of the air, as is proved by sudden disturbances which often come after the new moon, in the midst of a calm and of a stillness in the winds, to agitate the clouds and to hurl them against each other; as the flux and reflux in straits, and the ebb and flow of the ocean prove, so that those who live on its shores see it regularly following the revolutions of the moon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:214
verses.text: The waters of straits approach and retreat from one shore to the other during the different phases of the moon; but, when she is new, they have not an instant of rest, and move in perpetual swaying to and fro, until the moon, reappearing, regulates their reflux.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:215
verses.text: As to the Western sea, we see it in its ebb and flow now return into its bed, and now overflow, as the moon draws it back by her respiration and then, by her expiration, urges it to its own boundaries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:216
verses.text: I have entered into these details, to show you the grandeur of the luminaries, and to make you see that, in the inspired words, there is not one idle syllable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:217
verses.text: And yet my sermon has scarcely touched on any important point; there are many other discoveries about the size and distance of the sun and moon to which any one who will make a serious study of their action and of their characteristics may arrive by the aid of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:218
verses.text: Let me then ingenuously make an avowal of my weakness, for fear that you should measure the mighty works of the Creator by my words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:219
verses.text: The little that I have said ought the rather to make you conjecture the marvels on which I have omitted to dwell.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:220
verses.text: We must not then measure the moon with the eye, but with the reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:221
verses.text: Reason, for the discovery of truth, is much surer than the eye.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:222
verses.text: Everywhere ridiculous old women's tales, imagined in the delirium of drunkenness, have been circulated; such as that enchantments can remove the moon from its place and make it descend to the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:223
verses.text: How could a magician's charm shake that of which the Most High has laid the foundations? And if once torn out what place could hold it?  Do you wish from slight indications to have a proof of the moon's size? All the towns in the world, however distant from each other, equally receive the light from the moon in those streets that are turned towards its rising.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:224
verses.text: If she did not look on all face to face, those only would be entirely lighted up which were exactly opposite; as to those beyond the extremities of her disc, they would only receive diverted and oblique rays.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:225
verses.text: It is this effect which the light of lamps produces in houses; if a lamp is surrounded by several persons, only the shadow of the person who is directly opposite to it is cast in a straight line, the others follow inclined lines on each side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:226
verses.text: In the same way, if the body of the moon were not of an immense and prodigious size she could not extend herself alike to all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:227
verses.text: In reality, when the moon rises in the equinoctial regions, all equally enjoy her light, both those who inhabit the icy zone, under the revolutions of the Bear, and those who dwell in the extreme south in the neighbourhood of the torrid zone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:228
verses.text: She gives us an idea of her size by appearing to be face to face with all people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:229
verses.text: Who then can deny the immensity of a body which divides itself equally over such a wide extent?  But enough on the greatness of the sun and moon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:230
verses.text: May He Who has given us intelligence to recognise in the smallest objects of creation the great wisdom of the Contriver make us find in great bodies a still higher idea of their Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:231
verses.text: However, compared with their Author, the sun and moon are but a fly and an ant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:232
verses.text: The whole universe cannot give us a right idea of the greatness of God; and it is only by signs, weak and slight in themselves, often by the help of the smallest insects and of the least plants, that we raise ourselves to Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:233
verses.text: Content with these words let us offer our thanks, I to Him who has given me the ministry of the Word, you to Him who feeds you with spiritual food; Who, even at this moment, makes you find in my weak voice the strength of barley bread.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 6:234
verses.text: May He feed you for ever, and in proportion to your faith grant you the manifestation of the Spirit in Jesus Christ our Lord, to whom be glory and power for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:2
verses.text: The creation of moving creatures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:4
verses.text: "And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life" after their kind, "and fowl that may fly above the earth" after their kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:5
verses.text: After the creation of the luminaries the waters are now filled with living beings and its own adornment is given to this part of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:6
verses.text: Earth had received hers from her own plants, the heavens had received the flowers of the stars, and, like two eyes, the great luminaries beautified them in concert.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:7
verses.text: It still remained for the waters to receive their adornment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:8
verses.text: The command was given, and immediately the rivers and lakes becoming fruitful brought forth their natural broods; the sea travailed with all kinds of swimming creatures; not even in mud and marshes did the water remain idle; it took its part in creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:9
verses.text: Everywhere from its ebullition frogs, gnats and flies came forth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:10
verses.text: For that which we see to-day is the sign of the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:11
verses.text: Thus everywhere the water hastened to obey the Creator's command.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:12
verses.text: Who could count the species which the great and ineffable power of God caused to be suddenly seen living and moving, when this command had empowered the waters to bring forth life? Let the waters bring forth moving creatures that have life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:13
verses.text: Then for the first time is made a being with life and feeling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:14
verses.text: For though plants and trees be said to live, seeing that they share the power of being nourished and growing; nevertheless they are neither living beings, nor have they life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:15
verses.text: To create these last God said, "Let the water produce moving creatures".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:16
verses.text: Every creature that swims, whether it skims on the surface of the waters, or cleaves the depths, is of the nature of a moving creature, since it drags itself on the body of the water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:17
verses.text: Certain aquatic animals have feet and walk; especially amphibia, such as seals, crabs, crocodiles, river horses and frogs; but they are above all gifted with the power of swimming.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:18
verses.text: Thus it is said, Let the waters produce moving creatures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:19
verses.text: In these few words what species is omitted? Which is not included in the command of the Creator? Do we not see viviparous animals, seals, dolphins, rays and all cartilaginous animals? Do we not see oviparous animals comprising every sort of fish, those which have a skin and those which have scales, those which have fins and those which have not? This command has only required one word, even less than a word, a sign, a motion of the divine will, and it has such a wide sense that it includes all the varieties and all the families of fish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:20
verses.text: To review them all would be to undertake to count the waves of the ocean or to measure its waters in the hollow of the hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:21
verses.text: "Let the waters produce moving creatures".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:22
verses.text: That is to say, those which people the high seas and those which love the shores; those which inhabit the depths and those which attach themselves to rocks; those which are gregarious and those which live dispersed, the cetaceous, the huge, and the tiny.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:23
verses.text: It is from the same power, the same command, that all, small and great receive their existence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:24
verses.text: "Let the waters bring forth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:25
verses.text: These words show you the natural affinity of animals which swim in the water; thus, fish, when drawn out of the water, quickly die, because they have no respiration such as could attract our air and water is their element, as air is that of terrestrial animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:26
verses.text: The reason for it is clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:27
verses.text: With us the lung, that porous and spongy portion of the inward parts which receives air by the dilatation of the chest, disperses and cools interior warmth; in fish the motion of the gills, which open and shut by turns to take in and to eject the water, takes the place of respiration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:28
verses.text: Fish have a peculiar lot, a special nature, a nourishment of their own, a life apart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:29
verses.text: Thus they cannot be tamed and cannot bear the touch of a man's hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:31
verses.text: "Let the waters bring forth moving creatures after their kind".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:32
verses.text: God caused to be born the firstlings of each species to serve as seeds for nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:33
verses.text: Their multitudinous numbers are kept up in subsequent succession, when it is necessary for them to grow and multiply.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:34
verses.text: Of another kind is the species of testacea, as muscles, scallops, sea snails, conches, and the infinite variety of oysters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:35
verses.text: Another kind is that of the crustacea, as crabs and lobsters; another of fish without shells, with soft and tender flesh, like polypi and cuttle fish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:36
verses.text: And amidst these last what an innumerable variety! There are weevers, lampreys and eels, produced in the mud of rivers and ponds, which more resemble venomous reptiles than fish in their nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:37
verses.text: Of another kind is the species of the ovipara; of another, that of the vivipara.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:38
verses.text: Among the latter are sword-fish, cod, in one word, all cartilaginous fish, and even the greater part of the cetacea, as dolphins, seals, which, it is said, if they see their little ones, still quite young, frightened, take them back into their belly to protect them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:39
verses.text: Let the waters bring forth after their kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:40
verses.text: The species of the cetacean is one; another is that of small fish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:41
verses.text: What infinite variety in the different kinds! All have their own names, different food, different form, shape, and quality of flesh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:42
verses.text: All present infinite variety, and are divided into innumerable classes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:43
verses.text: Is there a tunny fisher who can enumerate to us the different varieties of that fish? And yet they tell us that at the sight of great swarms of fish they can almost tell the number of the individual ones which compose it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:44
verses.text: What man is there of all that have spent their long lives by coasts and shores, who can inform us with exactness of the history of all fish?  Some are known to the fishermen of the Indian ocean, others to the toilers of the Egyptian gulf, others to the islanders, others to the men of Mauretania.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:45
verses.text: Great and small were all alike created by this first command, by this ineffable power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:46
verses.text: What a difference in their food! What a variety in the manner in which each species reproduces itself! Most fish do not hatch eggs like birds; they do not build nests; they do not feed their young with toil; it is the water which receives and vivifies the egg dropped into it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:47
verses.text: With them the reproduction of each species is invariable, and natures are not mixed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:48
verses.text: There are none of those unions which, on the earth, produce mules and certain birds contrary to the nature of their species.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:49
verses.text: With fish there is no variety which, like the ox and the sheep, is armed with a half-equipment of teeth, none which ruminates except, according to certain writers, the scar.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:50
verses.text: All have serried and very sharp teeth, for fear their food should escape them if they masticate it for too long a time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:51
verses.text: In fact, if it were not crushed and swallowed as soon as divided, it would be carried away by the water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:53
verses.text: The food of fish differs according to their species.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:54
verses.text: Some feed on mud; others eat sea weed; others content themselves with the herbs that grow in water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:55
verses.text: But the greater part devour each other, and the smaller is food for the larger, and if one which has possessed itself of a fish weaker than itself becomes a prey to another, the conqueror and the conquered are both swallowed up in the belly of the last.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:56
verses.text: And we mortals, do we act otherwise when we press our inferiors? What difference is there between the last fish and the man who, impelled by devouring greed, swallows the weak in the folds of his insatiable avarice? Yon fellow possessed the goods of the poor; you caught him and made him a part of your abundance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:57
verses.text: You have shown yourself more unjust than the unjust, and more miserly than the miser.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:58
verses.text: Look to it lest you end like the fish, by hook, by weel, or by net.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:59
verses.text: Surely we too, when we have done the deeds of the wicked, shall not escape punishment at the last.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:60
verses.text: Now see what tricks, what cunning, are to be found in a weak animal, and learn not to imitate wicked doers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:61
verses.text: The crab loves the flesh of the oyster; but, sheltered by its shell, a solid rampart with which nature has furnished its soft and delicate flesh, it is a difficult prey to seize.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:62
verses.text: Thus they call the oyster "sherd-hide".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:63
verses.text: Thanks to the two shells with which it is enveloped, and which adapt themselves perfectly the one to the other, the claws of the crab are quite powerless.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:64
verses.text: What does he do? When he sees it, sheltered from the wind, warming itself with pleasure, and half opening its shells to the sun, he secretly throws in a pebble, prevents them from closing, and takes by cunning what force had lost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:65
verses.text: Such is the malice of these animals, deprived as they are of reason and of speech.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:66
verses.text: But I would that you should at once rival the crab in cunning and industry, and abstain from harming your neighbour; this animal is the image of him who craftily approaches his brother, takes advantage of his neighbour's misfortunes, and finds his delight in other men's troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:67
verses.text: O copy not the damned! Content yourself with your own lot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:68
verses.text: Poverty, with what is necessary, is of more value in the eyes of the wise than all pleasures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:69
verses.text: I will not pass in silence the cunning and trickery of the squid, which takes the colour of the rock to which it attaches itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:70
verses.text: Most fish swim idly up to the squid as they might to a rock, and become themselves the prey of the crafty creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:71
verses.text: Such are men who court ruling powers, bending themselves to all circumstances and not remaining for a moment in the same purpose; who praise self-restraint in the company of the self-restrained, and license in that of the licentious, accommodating their feelings to the pleasure of each.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:72
verses.text: It is difficult to escape them and to put ourselves on guard against their mischief; because it is under the mask of friendship that they hide their clever wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:73
verses.text: Men like this are ravening wolves covered with sheep's clothing, as the Lord calls them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:74
verses.text: Flee then fickleness and pliability; seek truth, sincerity, simplicity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:75
verses.text: The serpent is shifty; so he has been condemned to crawl.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:76
verses.text: The just is an honest man, like Job.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:77
verses.text: Wherefore God setteth the solitary in families.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:78
verses.text: So is this great and wide sea, wherein are things creeping innumerable, both small and great beasts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:79
verses.text: Yet a wise and marvellous order reigns among these animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:80
verses.text: Fish do not always deserve our reproaches; often they offer us useful examples.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:81
verses.text: How is it that each sort of fish, content with the region that has been assigned to it, never travels over its own limits to pass into foreign seas? No surveyor has ever distributed to them their habitations, nor enclosed them in walls, nor assigned limits to them; each kind has been naturally assigned its own home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:82
verses.text: One gulf nourishes one kind of fish, another other sorts; those which swarm here are absent elsewhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:83
verses.text: No mountain raises its sharp peaks between them; no rivers bar the passage to them; it is a law of nature, which according to the needs of each kind, has allotted to them their dwelling places with equality and justice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:85
verses.text: It is not thus with us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:86
verses.text: Why? Because we incessantly move the ancient landmarks which our fathers have set.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:87
verses.text: We encroach, we add house to house, field to field, to enrich ourselves at the expense of our neighbour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:88
verses.text: The great fish know the sojourning place that nature has assigned to them; they occupy the sea far from the haunts of men, where no islands lie, and where are no continents rising to confront them, because it has never been crossed and neither curiosity nor need has persuaded sailors to tempt it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:89
verses.text: The monsters that dwell in this sea are in size like high mountains, so witnesses who have seen tell us, and never cross their boundaries to ravage islands and seaboard towns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:90
verses.text: Thus each kind is as if it were stationed in towns, in villages, in an ancient country, and has for its dwelling place the regions of the sea which have been assigned to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:91
