verses.text: Instances have, however, been known of migratory fish, who, as if common deliberation transported them into strange regions, all start on their march at a given sign.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:92
verses.text: When the time marked for breeding arrives, they, as if awakened by a common law of nature, migrate from gulf to gulf, directing their course toward the North Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:93
verses.text: And at the epoch of their return you may see all these fish streaming like a torrent across the Propontis towards the Euxine Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:94
verses.text: Who puts them in marching array? Where is the prince's order? Has an edict affixed in the public place indicated to them their day of departure? Who serves them as a guide? See how the divine order embraces all and extends to the smallest object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:95
verses.text: A fish does not resist God's law, and we men cannot endure His precepts of salvation! Do not despise fish because they are dumb and quite unreasoning; rather fear lest, in your resistance to the disposition of the Creator, you have even less reason than they.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:96
verses.text: Listen to the fish, who by their actions all but speak and say: it is for the perpetuation of our race that we undertake this long voyage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:97
verses.text: They have not the gift of reason, but they have the law of nature firmly seated within them, to show them what they have to do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:98
verses.text: Let us go, they say, to the North Sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:99
verses.text: Its water is sweeter than that of the rest of the sea; for the sun does not remain long there, and its rays do not draw up all the drinkable portions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:100
verses.text: Even sea creatures love fresh water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:101
verses.text: Thus one often sees them enter into rivers and swim far up them from the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:102
verses.text: This is the reason which makes them prefer the Euxine Sea to other gulfs, as the most fit for breeding and for bringing up their young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:103
verses.text: When they have obtained their object the whole tribe returns home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:104
verses.text: Let us hear these dumb creatures tell us the reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:105
verses.text: The Northern sea, they say, is shallow and its surface is exposed to the violence of the wind, and it has few shores and retreats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:106
verses.text: Thus the winds easily agitate it to its bottom and mingle the sands of its bed with its waves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:107
verses.text: Besides, it is cold in winter, filled as it is from all directions by large rivers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:108
verses.text: Wherefore after a moderate enjoyment of its waters, during the summer, when the winter comes they hasten to reach warmer depths and places heated by the sun, and after fleeing from the stormy tracts of the North, they seek a haven in less agitated seas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:110
verses.text: I myself have seen these marvels, and I have admired the wisdom of God in all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:111
verses.text: If beings deprived of reason are capable of thinking and of providing for their own preservation; if a fish knows what it ought to seek and what to shun, what shall we say, who are honoured with reason, instructed by law, encouraged by the promises, made wise by the Spirit, and are nevertheless less reasonable about our own affairs than the fish? They know how to provide for the future, but we renounce our hope of the future and spend our life in brutal indulgence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:112
verses.text: A fish traverses the extent of the sea to find what is good for it; what will you say then—you who live in idleness, the mother of all vices? Do not let any one make his ignorance an excuse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:113
verses.text: There has been implanted in us natural reason which tells us to identify ourselves with good, and to avoid all that is harmful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:114
verses.text: I need not go far from the sea to find examples, as that is the object of our researches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:115
verses.text: I have heard it said by one living near the sea, that the sea urchin, a little contemptible creature, often foretells calm and tempest to sailors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:116
verses.text: When it foresees a disturbance of the winds, it gets under a great pebble, and clinging to it as to an anchor, it tosses about in safety, retained by the weight which prevents it from becoming the plaything of the waves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:117
verses.text: It is a certain sign for sailors that they are threatened with a violent agitation of the winds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:118
verses.text: No astrologer, no Chaldaean, reading in the rising of the stars the disturbances of the air, has ever communicated his secret to the urchin: it is the Lord of the sea and of the winds who has impressed on this little animal a manifest proof of His great wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:119
verses.text: God has foreseen all, He has neglected nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:120
verses.text: His eye, which never sleeps, watches over all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:121
verses.text: He is present everywhere and gives to each being the means of preservation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:122
verses.text: If God has not left the sea urchin outside His providence, is He without care for you?  "Husbands love your wives".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:123
verses.text: Although formed of two bodies you are united to live in the communion of wedlock.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:124
verses.text: May this natural link, may this yoke imposed by the blessing, reunite those who are divided.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:125
verses.text: The viper, the cruelest of reptiles, unites itself with the sea lamprey, and, announcing its presence by a hiss, it calls it from the depths to conjugal union.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:126
verses.text: The lamprey obeys, and is united to this venomous animal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:127
verses.text: What does this mean? However hard, however fierce a husband may be, the wife ought to bear with him, and not wish to find any pretext for breaking the union.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:128
verses.text: He strikes you, but he is your husband.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:129
verses.text: He is a drunkard, but he is united to you by nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:130
verses.text: He is brutal and cross, but he is henceforth one of your members, and the most precious of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:132
verses.text: Let husbands listen as well: here is a lesson for them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:133
verses.text: The viper vomits forth its venom in respect for marriage; and you, will you not put aside the barbarity and the inhumanity of your soul, out of respect for your union? Perhaps the example of the viper contains another meaning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:134
verses.text: The union of the viper and of the lamprey is an adulterous violation of nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:135
verses.text: You, who are plotting against other men's wedlock, learn what creeping creature you are like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:136
verses.text: I have only one object, to make all I say turn to the edification of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:137
verses.text: Let then libertines put a restraint on their passions, for they are taught by the examples set by creatures of earth and sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:138
verses.text: My bodily infirmity and the lateness of the hour force me to end my discourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:139
verses.text: However, I have still many observations to make on the products of the sea, for the admiration of my attentive audience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:140
verses.text: To speak of the sea itself, how does its water change into salt? How is it that coral, a stone so much esteemed, is a plant in the midst of the sea, and when once exposed to the air becomes hard as a rock? Why has nature enclosed in the meanest of animals, in an oyster, so precious an object as a pearl? For these pearls, which are coveted by the caskets of kings, are cast upon the shores, upon the coasts, upon sharp rocks, and enclosed in oyster shells.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:141
verses.text: How can the sea pinna produce her fleece of gold, which no dye has ever imitated? How can shells give kings purple of a brilliancy not surpassed by the flowers of the field?  "Let the waters bring forth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:142
verses.text: What necessary object was there that did not immediately appear? What object of luxury was not given to man? Some to supply his needs, some to make him contemplate the marvels of creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:143
verses.text: Some are terrible, so as to take our idleness to school.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:144
verses.text: "God created great whales".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:145
verses.text: Scripture gives them the name of "great" not because they are greater than a shrimp and a sprat, but because the size of their bodies equals that of great hills.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:146
verses.text: Thus when they swim on the surface of the waters one often sees them appear like islands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:147
verses.text: But these monstrous creatures do not frequent our coasts and shores; they inhabit the Atlantic ocean.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:148
verses.text: Such are these animals created to strike us with terror and awe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:149
verses.text: If now you hear say that the greatest vessels, sailing with full sails, are easily stopped by a very small fish, by the remora, and so forcibly that the ship remains motionless for a long time, as if it had taken root in the middle of the sea, do you not see in this little creature a like proof of the power of the Creator? Sword fish, saw fish, dog fish, whales, and sharks, are not therefore the only things to be dreaded; we have to fear no less the spike of the stingray even after its death, and the sea-hare, whose mortal blows are as rapid as they are inevitable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:150
verses.text: Thus the Creator wishes that all may keep you awake, so that full of hope in Him you may avoid the evils with which all these creatures threaten you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:151
verses.text: But let us come out of the depths of the sea and take refuge upon the shore.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:152
verses.text: For the marvels of creation, coming one after the other in constant succession like the waves, have submerged my discourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:153
verses.text: However, I should not be surprised if, after finding greater wonders upon the earth, my spirit seeks like Jonah's to flee to the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:154
verses.text: But it seems to me, that meeting with these innumerable marvels has made me forget all measure, and experience the fate of those who navigate the high seas without a fixed point to mark their progress, and are often ignorant of the space which they have traversed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:155
verses.text: This is what has happened to me; whilst my words glanced at creation, I have not been sensible of the multitude of beings of which I spoke to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:156
verses.text: But although this honourable assembly is pleased by my speech, and the recital of the marvels of the Master is grateful to the ears of His servants, let me here bring the ship of my discourse to anchor, and await the day to deliver you the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:157
verses.text: Let us, therefore, all arise, and, giving thanks for what has been said, let us ask for strength to hear the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:158
verses.text: Whilst taking your food may the conversation at your table turn upon what has occupied us this morning and this evening.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 7:159
verses.text: Filled with these thoughts may you, even in sleep, enjoy the pleasure of the day, so that you may be permitted to say, "I sleep but my heart waketh," meditating day and night upon the law of the Lord, to Whom be glory and power world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:2
verses.text: The creation of fowl and water animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:4
verses.text: And God said "Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle and creeping things, and beast of the earth after his kind; and it was so".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:5
verses.text: The command of God advanced step by step and earth thus received her adornment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:6
verses.text: Yesterday it was said, "Let the waters produce moving things," and to-day "let the earth bring forth the living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:7
verses.text: Is the earth then alive? And are the mad-minded Manichaeans right in giving it a soul? At these words "Let the earth bring forth," it did not produce a germ contained in it, but He who gave the order at the same time gifted it with the grace and power to bring forth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:8
verses.text: When the earth had heard this command "Let the earth bring forth grass and the tree yielding fruit," it was not grass that it had hidden in it that it caused to spring forth, it did not bring to the surface a palm tree, an oak, a cypress, hitherto kept back in its depths.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:9
verses.text: It is the word of God which forms the nature of things created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:10
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth;" that is to say not that she may bring forth that which she has but that she may acquire that which she lacks, when God gives her the power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:11
verses.text: Even so now, "Let the earth bring forth the living creature," not the living creature that is contained in herself, but that which the command of God gives her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:12
verses.text: Further, the Manichaeans contradict themselves, because if the earth has brought forth the life, she has left herself despoiled of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:13
verses.text: Their execrable doctrine needs no demonstration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:14
verses.text: But why did the waters receive the command to bring forth the moving creature that hath life and the earth to bring forth the living creature? We conclude that, by their nature, swimming creatures appear only to have an imperfect life, because they live in the thick element of water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:15
verses.text: They are hard of hearing, and their sight is dull because they see through the water; they have no memory, no imagination, no idea of social intercourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:16
verses.text: Thus divine language appears to indicate that, in aquatic animals, the carnal life originates their psychic movements, whilst in terrestrial animals, gifted with a more perfect life, the soul enjoys supreme authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:17
verses.text: In fact the greater part of quadrupeds have more power of penetration in their senses; their apprehension of present objects is keen, and they keep all exact remembrance of the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:18
verses.text: It seems therefore, that God, after the command given to the waters to bring forth moving creatures that have life, created simply living bodies for aquatic animals, whilst for terrestrial animals He commanded the soul to exist and to direct the body, showing thus that the inhabitants of the earth are gifted with greater vital force.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:19
verses.text: Without doubt terrestrial animals are devoid of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:20
verses.text: At the same time how many affections of the soul each one of them expresses by the voice of nature! They express by cries their joy and sadness, recognition of what is familiar to them, the need of food, regret at being separated from their companions, and numberless emotions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:21
verses.text: Aquatic animals, on the contrary, are not only dumb; it is impossible to tame them, to teach them, to train them for man's society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:22
verses.text: "The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:23
verses.text: But the fish does not know who feeds him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:24
verses.text: The ass knows a familiar voice, he knows the road which he has often trodden, and even, if man loses his way, he sometimes serves him as a guide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:25
verses.text: His hearing is more acute than that of any other terrestrial animal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:26
verses.text: What animal of the sea can show so much rancour and resentment as the camel? The camel conceals its resentment for a long time after it has been struck, until it finds an opportunity, and then repays the wrong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:27
verses.text: Listen, you whose heart does not pardon, you who practise vengeance as a virtue; see what you resemble when you keep your anger for so long against your neighbour like a spark, hidden in the ashes, and only waiting for fuel to set your heart ablaze!  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:28
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth a living soul".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:29
verses.text: Why did the earth produce a living soul? so that you may make a difference between the soul of cattle and that of man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:30
verses.text: You will soon learn how the human soul was formed; hear now about the soul of creatures devoid of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:31
verses.text: Since, according to Scripture, "the life of every creature is in the blood," as the blood when thickened changes into flesh, and flesh when corrupted decomposes into earth, so the soul of beasts is naturally an earthy substance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:32
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth a living soul".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:33
verses.text: See the affinity of the soul with blood, of blood with flesh, of flesh with earth; and remounting in an inverse sense from the earth to the flesh, from the flesh to the blood, from the blood to the soul, you will find that the soul of beasts is earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:34
verses.text: Do not suppose that it is older than the essence of their body, nor that it survives the dissolution of the flesh; avoid the nonsense of those arrogant philosophers who do not blush to liken their soul to that of a dog; who say that they have been formerly themselves women, shrubs, fish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:35
verses.text: Have they ever been fish? I do not know; but I do not fear to affirm that in their writings they show less sense than fish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:36
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:37
verses.text: Perhaps many of you ask why there is such a long silence in the middle of the rapid rush of my discourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:38
verses.text: The more studious among my auditors will not be ignorant of the reason why words fail me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:39
verses.text: What! Have I not seen them look at each other, and make signs to make me look at them, and to remind me of what I have passed over? I have forgotten a part of the creation, and that one of the most considerable, and my discourse was almost finished without touching upon it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:40
verses.text: "Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament, of heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:41
verses.text: I spoke of fish as long as eventide allowed: to-day we have passed to the examination of terrestrial animals; between the two, birds have escaped us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:42
verses.text: We are forgetful like travellers who unmindful of some important object, are obliged, although they be far on their road, to retrace their steps, punished for their negligence by the weariness of the journey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:43
verses.text: So we have to turn back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:44
verses.text: That which we have omitted is not to be despised.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:45
verses.text: It is the third part of the animal creation, if indeed there are three kinds of animals, land, winged and water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:46
verses.text: "Let the waters" it is said "bring forth abundantly moving creature that hath life and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:47
verses.text: Why do the waters give birth also to birds? Because there is, so to say, a family link between the creatures that fly and those that swim.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:48
verses.text: In the same way that fish cut the waters, using their fins to carry them forward and their tails to direct their movements round and round and straightforward, so we see birds float in the air by the help of their wings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:49
verses.text: Both endowed with the property of swimming, their common derivation from the waters has made them of one family.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:50
verses.text: At the same time no bird is without feet, because finding all its food upon the earth it cannot do without their service.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:51
verses.text: Rapacious birds have pointed claws to enable them to close on their prey; to the rest has been given the indispensable ministry of feet to seek their food and to provide for the other needs of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:52
verses.text: There are a few who walk badly, whose feet are neither suitable for walking nor for preying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:53
verses.text: Among this number are swallows, incapable of walking and seeking their prey, and the birds called swifts who live on little insects carried about by the air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:54
verses.text: As to the swallow, its flight, which grazes the earth, fulfils the function of feet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:56
verses.text: There are also innumerable kinds of birds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:57
verses.text: If we review them all, as we have partly done the fish, we shall find that under one name, the creatures which fly differ infinitely in size, form and colour; that in their life, their actions and their manners, they present a variety equally beyond the power of description.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:58
verses.text: Thus some have tried to imagine names for them of which the singularity and the strangeness might, like brands, mark the distinctive character of each kind known.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:59
verses.text: Some, as eagles, have been called Schizoptera, others Dermoptera, as the bats, others Ptilota, as wasps, others Coleoptera, as beetles and all those insects which brought forth in cases and coverings, break their prison to fly away in liberty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:60
verses.text: But we have enough words of common usage to characterise each species and to mark the distinction which Scripture sets up between clean and unclean birds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:61
verses.text: Thus the species of carnivora is of one sort and of one constitution which suits their manner of living, sharp talons, curved beak, swift wings, allowing them to swoop easily upon their prey and to tear it up after having seized it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:62
verses.text: The constitution of those who pick up seeds is different, and again that of those who live on all they come across.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:63
verses.text: What a variety in all these creatures! Some are gregarious, except the birds of prey who know no other society than conjugal union; but innumerable kinds, doves, cranes, starlings, jackdaws, like a common life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:64
verses.text: Among them some live without a chief and in a sort of independence; others, as cranes, do not refuse to submit themselves to a leader.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:65
verses.text: And a fresh difference between them is that some are stationary and non-migratory; others undertake long voyages and the greater part of them migrate at the approach of winter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:66
verses.text: Nearly all birds can be tamed and are capable of training, except the weakest, who through fear and timidity cannot bear the constant and annoying contact of the hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:67
verses.text: Some like the society of man and inhabit our dwellings; others delight in mountains and in desert places.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:68
verses.text: There is a great difference too in their peculiar notes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:69
verses.text: Some twitter and chatter, others are silent, some have a melodious and sonorous voice, some are wholly inharmonious and incapable of song; some imitate the voice of man, taught their mimicry either by nature or training; others always give forth the same monotonous cry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:70
verses.text: The cock is proud; the peacock is vain of his beauty; doves and fowls are amorous, always seeking each other's society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:71
verses.text: The partridge is deceitful and jealous, lending perfidious help to the huntsmen to seize their prey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:73
verses.text: What a variety, I have said, in the actions and lives of flying creatures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:74
verses.text: Some of these unreasoning creatures even have a government, if the feature of government is to make the activity of all the individuals centre in one common end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:75
verses.text: This may be observed in bees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:76
verses.text: They have a common dwelling place; they fly in the air together, they work at the same work together; and what is still more extraordinary is that they give themselves to these labours under the guidance of a king and superintendent, and that they do not allow themselves to fly to the meadows without seeing if the king is flying at their head.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:77
verses.text: As to this king, it is not election that gives him this authority; ignorance on the part of the people often puts the worst man in power; it is not fate; the blind decisions of fate often give authority to the most unworthy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:78
verses.text: It is not heredity that places him on the throne; it is only too common to see the children of kings, corrupted by luxury and flattery, living in ignorance of all virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:79
verses.text: It is nature which makes the king of the bees, for nature gives him superior size, beauty, and sweetness of character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:80
verses.text: He has a sting like the others, but he does not use it to revenge himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:81
verses.text: It is a principle of natural and unwritten law, that those who are raised to high office, ought to be lenient in punishing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:82
verses.text: Even bees who do not follow the example of their king, repent without delay of their imprudence, since they lose their lives with their sting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:83
verses.text: Listen, Christians, you to whom it is forbidden to "recompense evil for evil" and commanded "to overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:84
verses.text: Take the bee for your model, which constructs its cells without injuring any one and without interfering with the goods of others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:85
verses.text: It gathers openly wax from the flowers with its mouth, drawing in the honey scattered over them like dew, and injects it into the hollow of its cells.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:86
verses.text: Thus at first honey is liquid; time thickens it and gives it its sweetness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:87
verses.text: The book of Proverbs has given the bee the most honourable and the best praise by calling her wise and industrious.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:88
verses.text: How much activity she exerts in gathering this precious nourishment, by which both kings and men of low degree are brought to health! How great is the art and cunning she displays in the construction of the store houses which are destined to receive the honey! After having spread the wax like a thin membrane, she distributes it in contiguous compartments which, weak though they are, by their number and by their mass, sustain the whole edifice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:89
verses.text: Each cell in fact holds to the one next to it, and is separated by a thin partition; we thus see two or three galleries of cells built one upon the other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:90
verses.text: The bee takes care not to make one vast cavity, for fear it might break under the weight of the liquid, and allow it to escape.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:91
verses.text: See how the discoveries of geometry are mere by-works to the wise bee!  The rows of honey-comb are all hexagonal with equal sides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:92
verses.text: They do not bear on each other in straight lines, lest the supports should press on empty spaces between and give way; but the angles of the lower hexagons serve as foundations and bases to those which rise above, so as to furnish a sure support to the lower mass, and so that each cell may securely keep the liquid honey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:94
verses.text: How shall we make an exact review of all the peculiarities of the life of birds? During the night cranes keep watch in turn; some sleep, others make the rounds and procure a quiet slumber for their companions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:95
verses.text: After having finished his duty, the sentry utters a cry, and goes to sleep, and the one who awakes, in his turn, repays the security which he has enjoyed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:96
verses.text: You will see the same order reign in their flight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:97
verses.text: One leads the way, and when it has guided the flight of the flock for a certain time, it passes to the rear, leaving to the one who comes after the care of directing the march.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:98
verses.text: The conduct of storks comes very near intelligent reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:99
verses.text: In these regions the same season sees them all migrate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:100
verses.text: They all start at one given signal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:101
verses.text: And it seems to me that our crows, serving them as escort, go to bring them back, and to help them against the attacks of hostile birds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:102
verses.text: The proof is that in this season not a single crow appears, and that they return with wounds, evident marks of the help and of the assistance that they have lent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:103
verses.text: Who has explained to them the laws of hospitality? Who has threatened them with the penalties of desertion? For not one is missing from the company.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:104
verses.text: Listen, all inhospitable hearts, ye who shut your doors, whose house is never open either in the winter or in the night to travellers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:105
verses.text: The solicitude of storks for their old would be sufficient, if our children would reflect upon it, to make them love their parents; because there is no one so failing in good sense, as not to deem it a shame to be surpassed in virtue by birds devoid of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:106
verses.text: The storks surround their father, when old age makes his feathers drop off, warm him with their wings, and provide abundantly for his support, and even in their flight they help him as much as they are able, raising him gently on each side upon their wings, a conduct so notorious that it has given to gratitude the name of "antipelargosis".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:107
verses.text: Let no one lament poverty; let not the man whose house is bare despair of his life, when he considers the industry of the swallow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:108
verses.text: To build her nest, she brings bits of straw in her beak; and, as she cannot raise the mud in her claws, she moistens the end of her wings in water and then rolls in very fine dust and thus procures mud.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:109
verses.text: After having united, little by little, the bits of straw with this mud, as with glue, she feeds her young; and if any one of them has its eyes injured, she has a natural remedy to heal the sight of her little ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:110
verses.text: This sight ought to warn you not to take to evil ways on account of poverty; and, even if you are reduced to the last extremity, not to lose all hope; not to abandon yourself to inaction and idleness, but to have recourse to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:111
verses.text: If He is so bountiful to the swallow, what will He not do for those who call upon Him with all their heart?  The halcyon is a sea bird, which lays its eggs along the shore, or deposits them in the sand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:112
verses.text: And it lays in the middle of winter, when the violence of the winds dashes the sea against the land.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:113
verses.text: Yet all winds are hushed, and the wave of the sea grows calm, during the seven days that the halcyon sits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:114
verses.text: For it only takes seven days to hatch the young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:115
verses.text: Then, as they are in need of food so that they may grow, God, in His munificence, grants another seven days to this tiny animal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:116
verses.text: All sailors know this, and call these days halcyon days.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:117
verses.text: If divine Providence has established these marvellous laws in favour of creatures devoid of reason, it is to induce you to ask for your salvation from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:118
verses.text: Is there a wonder which He will not perform for you—you have been made in His image, when for so little a bird, the great, the fearful sea is held in check and is commanded in the midst of winter to be calm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:120
verses.text: It is said that the turtle-dove, once separated from her mate, does not contract a new union, but remains in widowhood, in remembrance of her first alliance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:121
verses.text: Listen, O women! What veneration for widowhood, even in these creatures devoid of reason, how they prefer it to an unbecoming multiplicity of marriages.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:122
verses.text: The eagle shows the greatest injustice in the education which she gives to her young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:123
verses.text: When she has hatched two little ones, she throws one on the ground, thrusting it out with blows from her wings, and only acknowledges the remaining one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:124
verses.text: It is the difficulty of finding food which has made her repulse the offspring she has brought forth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:125
verses.text: But the osprey, it is said, will not allow it to perish, she carries it away and brings it up with her young ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:126
verses.text: Such are parents who, under the plea of poverty, expose their children; such are again those who, in the distribution of their inheritance, make unequal divisions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:127
verses.text: Since they have given existence equally to each of their children, it is just that they should equally and without preference furnish them with the means of livelihood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:128
verses.text: Beware of imitating the cruelty of birds with hooked talons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:129
verses.text: When they see their young are from henceforth capable of encountering the air in their flight, they throw them out of the nest, striking them and pushing them with their wings, and do not take the least care of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:130
verses.text: The love of the crow for its young is laudable! When they begin to fly, she follows them, gives them food, and for a very long time provides for their nourishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:131
verses.text: Many birds have no need of union with males to conceive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:132
verses.text: But their eggs are unfruitful, except those of vultures, who more often, it is said, bring forth without coupling: and this although they have a very long life, which often reaches its hundredth year.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:133
verses.text: Note and retain, I pray you, this point in the history of birds; and if ever you see any one laugh at our mystery, as if it were impossible and contrary to nature that a virgin should become a mother without losing the purity of her virginity, bethink you that He who would save the faithful by the foolishness of preaching, has given us beforehand in nature a thousand reasons for believing in the marvellous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:135
verses.text: "Let the waters bring forth the moving creatures that have life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:136
verses.text: They received the command to fly above the earth because earth provides them with nourishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:137
verses.text: "In the firmament of heaven," that is to say, as we have said before, in that part of the air called οὐρανός, heaven, from the word ὁρᾶν, which means to see; called firmament, because the air which extends over our heads, compared to the aether, has greater density, and is thickened by the vapours which exhale from the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:138
verses.text: You have then heaven adorned, earth beautified, the sea peopled with its own creatures, the air filled with birds which scour it in every direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:139
verses.text: Studious listener, think of all these creations which God has drawn out of nothing, think of all those which my speech has left out, to avoid tediousness, and not to exceed my limits; recognise everywhere the wisdom of God; never cease to wonder, and, through every creature, to glorify the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:140
verses.text: There are some kinds of birds which live by night in the midst of darkness; others which fly by day in full light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:141
verses.text: Bats, owls, night-ravens are birds of night: if by chance you cannot sleep, reflect on these nocturnal birds and their peculiarities and glorify their Maker.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:142
verses.text: How is it that the nightingale is always awake when sitting on her eggs, passing the night in a continual melody? How is it that one animal, the bat, is at the same time quadruped and fowl? That it is the only one of the birds to have teeth? That it is viviparous like quadrupeds, and traverses the air, raising itself not upon wings, but upon a kind of membrane? What natural love bats have for each other! How they interlace like a chain and hang the one upon the other! A very rare spectacle among men, who for the greater part prefer individual and private life to the union of common life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:143
verses.text: Have not those who give themselves up to vain science the eyes of owls? The sight of the owl, piercing during the night time, is dazzled by the splendour of the sun; thus the intelligence of these men, so keen to contemplate vanities, is blind in presence of the true light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:144
verses.text: During the day, also, how easy it is for you to admire the Creator everywhere! See how the domestic cock calls you to work with his shrill cry, and how, forerunner of the sun, and early as the traveller, he sends forth labourers to the harvest! What vigilance in geese! With what sagacity they divine secret dangers! Did they not once upon a time save the imperial city? When enemies were advancing by subterranean passages to possess themselves of the capitol of Rome, did not geese announce the danger? Is there any kind of bird whose nature offers nothing for our admiration? Who announces to the vultures that there will be carnage when men march in battle array against one another? You may see flocks of vultures following armies and calculating the result of warlike preparations; a calculation very nearly approaching to human reasoning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:145
verses.text: How can I describe to you the fearful invasions of locusts, which rise everywhere at a given signal, and pitch their camps all over a country? They do not attack crops until they have received the divine command.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:146
verses.text: Or shall I describe how the remedy for this curse, the thrush, follows them with its insatiable appetite, and the devouring nature that the loving God has given it in His kindness for men? How does the grasshopper modulate its song? Why is it more melodious at midday owing to the air that it breathes in dilating its chest?  But it appears to me that in wishing to describe the marvels of winged creatures, I remain further behind than I should if my feet had tried to match the rapidity of their flight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:147
verses.text: When you see bees, wasps, in short all those flying creatures called insects, because they have an incision all around, reflect that they have neither respiration nor lungs, and that they are supported by air through all parts of their bodies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:148
verses.text: Thus they perish, if they are covered with oil, because it stops up their pores.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:149
verses.text: Wash them with vinegar, the pores reopen and the animal returns to life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:150
verses.text: Our God has created nothing unnecessarily and has omitted nothing that is necessary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:151
verses.text: If now you cast your eyes upon aquatic creatures, you will find that their organization is quite different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:152
verses.text: Their feet are not split like those of the crow, nor hooked like those of the carnivora, but large and membraneous; therefore they can easily swim, pushing the water with the membranes of their feet as with oars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:153
verses.text: Notice how the swan plunges his neck into the depths of the water to draw his food from it, and you will understand the wisdom of the Creator in giving this creature a neck longer than his feet, so that he may throw it like a line, and take the food hidden at the bottom of the water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:155
verses.text: If we simply read the words of Scripture we find only a few short syllables.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:156
verses.text: "Let the waters bring forth fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven," but if we enquire into the meaning of these words, then the great wonder of the wisdom of the Creator appears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:157
verses.text: What a difference He has foreseen among winged creatures! How He has divided them by kinds! How He has characterized each one of them by distinct qualities! But the day will not suffice me to recount the wonders of the air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:158
verses.text: Earth is calling me to describe wild beasts, reptiles and cattle, ready to show us in her turn sights rivalling those of plants, fish, and birds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:159
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the living soul" of domestic animals, of wild beasts, and of reptiles after their kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:160
verses.text: What have you to say, you who do not believe in the change that Paul promises you in the resurrection, when you see so many metamorphoses among creatures of the air? What are we not told of the horned worm of India! First it changes into a caterpillar, then becomes a buzzing insect, and not content with this form, it clothes itself, instead of wings, with loose, broad plates.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:161
verses.text: Thus, O women, when you are seated busy with your weaving, I mean of the silk which is sent you by the Chinese to make your delicate dresses, remember the metamorphoses of this creature, conceive a clear idea of the resurrection, and do not refuse to believe in the change that Paul announces for all men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:162
verses.text: But I am ashamed to see that my discourse oversteps the accustomed limits; if I consider the abundance of matters on which I have just discoursed to you, I feel that I am being borne beyond bounds; but when I reflect upon the inexhaustible wisdom which is displayed in the works of creation, I seem to be but at the beginning of my story.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:163
verses.text: Nevertheless, I have not detained you so long without profit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:164
verses.text: For what would you have done until the evening? You are not pressed by guests, nor expected at banquets.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:165
verses.text: Let me then employ this bodily fast to rejoice your souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:166
verses.text: You have often served the flesh for pleasure, to-day persevere in the ministry of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:167
verses.text: "Delight thyself also in the Lord and he shall give thee the desire of thine heart".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:168
verses.text: Do you love riches? Here are spiritual riches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:169
verses.text: "The judgments of the Lord are true and righteous altogether.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:170
verses.text: More to be desired are they than gold and precious stones".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:171
verses.text: Do you love enjoyment and pleasures? Behold the oracles of the Lord, which, for a healthy soul, are "sweeter than honey and the honey-comb".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:172
verses.text: If I let you go, and if I dismiss this assembly, some will run to the dice, where they will find bad language, sad quarrels and the pangs of avarice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:173
verses.text: There stands the devil, inflaming the fury of the players with the dotted bones, transporting the same sums of money from one side of the table to the other, now exalting one with victory and throwing the other into despair, now swelling the first with boasting and covering his rival with confusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:174
verses.text: Of what use is bodily fasting and filling the soul with innumerable evils? He who does not play spends his leisure elsewhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:175
verses.text: What frivolities come from his mouth! What follies strike his ears! Leisure without the fear of the Lord is, for those who do not know the value of time, a school of vice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:176
verses.text: I hope that my words will be profitable; at least by occupying you here they have prevented you from sinning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:177
verses.text: Thus the longer I keep you, the longer you are out of the way of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:178
verses.text: An equitable judge will deem that I have said enough, not if he considers the riches of creation, but if he thinks of our weakness and of the measure one ought to keep in that which tends to pleasure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:179
verses.text: Earth has welcomed you with its own plants, water with its fish, air with its birds; the continent in its turn is ready to offer you as rich treasures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:180
verses.text: But let us put an end to this morning banquet, for fear satiety may blunt your taste for the evening one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 8:181
verses.text: May He who has filled all with the works of His creation and has left everywhere visible memorials of His wonders, fill your hearts with all spiritual joys in Jesus Christ, our Lord, to whom belong glory and power, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:2
verses.text: The creation of terrestrial animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:4
verses.text: How did you like the fare of my morning's discourse? It seemed to me that I had the good intentions of a poor giver of a feast, who, ambitious of having the credit of keeping a good table saddens his guests by the poor supply of the more expensive dishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:5
verses.text: In vain he lavishly covers his table with his mean fare; his ambition only shows his folly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:6
verses.text: It is for you to judge if I have shared the same fate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:7
verses.text: Yet, whatever my discourse may have been, take care lest you disregard it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:8
verses.text: No one refused to sit at the table of Elisha; and yet he only gave his friends wild vegetables.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:9
verses.text: I know the laws of allegory, though less by myself than from the works of others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:10
verses.text: There are those truly, who do not admit the common sense of the Scriptures, for whom water is not water, but some other nature, who see in a plant, in a fish, what their fancy wishes, who change the nature of reptiles and of wild beasts to suit their allegories, like the interpreters of dreams who explain visions in sleep to make them serve their own ends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:11
verses.text: For me grass is grass; plant, fish, wild beast, domestic animal, I take all in the literal sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:12
verses.text: "For I am not ashamed of the gospel".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:13
verses.text: Those who have written about the nature of the universe have discussed at length the shape of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:14
verses.text: If it be spherical or cylindrical, if it resemble a disc and is equally rounded in all parts, or if it has the forth of a winnowing basket and is hollow in the middle; all these conjectures have been suggested by cosmographers, each one upsetting that of his predecessor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:15
verses.text: It will not lead me to give less importance to the creation of the universe, that the servant of God, Moses, is silent as to shapes; he has not said that the earth is a hundred and eighty thousand furlongs in circumference; he has not measured into what extent of air its shadow projects itself whilst the sun revolves around it, nor stated how this shadow, casting itself upon the moon, produces eclipses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:16
verses.text: He has passed over in silence, as useless, all that is unimportant for us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:17
verses.text: Shall I then prefer foolish wisdom to the oracles of the Holy Spirit? Shall I not rather exalt Him who, not wishing to fill our minds with these vanities, has regulated all the economy of Scripture in view of the edification and the making perfect of our souls? It is this which those seem to me not to have understood, who, giving themselves up to the distorted meaning of allegory, have undertaken to give a majesty of their own invention to Scripture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:18
verses.text: It is to believe themselves wiser than the Holy Spirit, and to bring forth their own ideas under a pretext of exegesis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:19
verses.text: Let us hear Scripture as it has been written.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:21
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:22
verses.text: Behold the word of God pervading creation, beginning even then the efficacy which is seen displayed to-day, and will be displayed to the end of the world! As a ball, which one pushes, if it meet a declivity, descends, carried by its form and the nature of the ground and does not stop until it has reached a level surface; so nature, once put in motion by the Divine command, traverses creation with an equal step, through birth and death, and keeps up the succession of kinds through resemblance, to the last.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:23
verses.text: Nature always makes a horse succeed to a horse, a lion to a lion, an eagle to an eagle, and preserving each animal by these uninterrupted successions she transmits it to the end of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:24
verses.text: Animals do not see their peculiarities destroyed or effaced by any length of time; their nature, as though it had been just constituted, follows the course of ages, for ever young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:25
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:26
verses.text: This command has continued and earth does not cease to obey the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:27
verses.text: For, if there are creatures which are successively produced by their predecessors, there are others that even to-day we see born from the earth itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:28
verses.text: In wet weather she brings forth grasshoppers and an immense number of insects which fly in the air and have no names because they are so small; she also produces mice and frogs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:29
verses.text: In the environs of Thebes in Egypt, after abundant rain in hot weather, the country is covered with field mice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:30
verses.text: We see mud alone produce eels; they do not proceed from an egg, nor in any other manner; it is the earth alone which gives them birth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:31
verses.text: Let the earth produce a living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:32
verses.text: Cattle are terrestrial and bent towards the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:33
verses.text: Man, a celestial growth, rises superior to them as much by the mould of his bodily conformation as by the dignity of his soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:34
verses.text: What is the form of quadrupeds? Their head is bent towards the earth and looks towards their belly, and only pursues their belly's good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:35
verses.text: Thy head, O man! is turned towards heaven; thy eyes look up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:36
verses.text: When therefore thou degradest thyself by the passions of the flesh, slave of thy belly, and thy lowest parts, thou approachest animals without reason and becomest like one of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:37
verses.text: Thou art called to more noble cares; "seek those things which are above where Christ sitteth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:38
verses.text: Raise thy soul above the earth; draw from its natural conformation the rule of thy conduct; fix thy conversation in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:39
verses.text: Thy true country is the heavenly Jerusalem; thy fellow-citizens and thy compatriots are "the first-born which are written in heaven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:41
verses.text: "Let the earth bring forth the living creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:42
verses.text: Thus when the soul of brutes appeared it was not concealed in the earth, but it was born by the command of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:43
verses.text: Brutes have one and the same soul of which the common characteristic is absence of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:44
verses.text: But each animal is distinguished by peculiar qualities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:45
verses.text: The ox is steady, the ass is lazy, the horse has strong passions, the wolf cannot be tamed, the fox is deceitful, the stag timid, the ant industrious, the dog grateful and faithful in his friendships.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:46
verses.text: As each animal was created the distinctive character of his nature appeared in him in due measure; in the lion spirit, taste for solitary life, an unsociable character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:47
verses.text: True tyrant of animals, he, in his natural arrogance, admits but few to share his honours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:48
verses.text: He disdains his yesterday's food and never returns to the remains of the prey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:49
verses.text: Nature has provided his organs of voice with such great force that often much swifter animals are caught by his roaring alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:50
verses.text: The panther, violent and impetuous in his leaps, has a body fitted for his activity and lightness, in accord with the movements of his soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:51
verses.text: The bear has a sluggish nature, ways of its own, a sly character, and is very secret; therefore it has an analogous body, heavy, thick, without articulations such as are necessary for a cold dweller in dens.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:52
verses.text: When we consider the natural and innate care that these creatures without reason take of their lives we shall be induced to watch over ourselves and to think of the salvation of our souls; or rather we shall be the more condemned when we are found falling short even of the imitation of brutes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:53
verses.text: The bear, which often gets severely wounded, cares for himself and cleverly fills the wounds with mullein, a plant whose nature is very astringent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:54
verses.text: You will also see the fox heal his wounds with droppings from the pine tree; the tortoise, gorged with the flesh of the viper, finds in the virtue of marjoram a specific against this venomous animal and the serpent heals sore eyes by eating fennel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:55
verses.text: And is not reasoning intelligence eclipsed by animals in their provision for atmospheric changes? Do we not see sheep, when winter is approaching, devouring grass with avidity as if to make provision for future scarcity? Do we not also see oxen, long confined in the winter season, recognise the return of spring by a natural sensation, and look to the end of their stables towards the doors, all turning their heads there by common consent? Studious observers have remarked that the hedgehog makes an opening at the two extremities of his hole.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:56
verses.text: If the wind from the north is going to blow he shuts up the aperture which looks towards the north; if the south wind succeeds it the animal passes to the northern door.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:57
verses.text: What lesson do these animals teach man? They not only show us in our Creator a care which extends to all beings, but a certain presentiment of future even in brutes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:58
verses.text: Then we ought not to attach ourselves to this present life and ought to give all heed to that which is to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:59
verses.text: Will you not be industrious for yourself, O man? And will you not lay up in the present age rest in that which is to come, after having seen the example of the ant? The ant during summer collects treasures for winter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:60
verses.text: Far from giving itself up to idleness, before this season has made it feel its severity, it hastens to work with an invincible zeal until it has abundantly filled its storehouses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:61
verses.text: Here again, how far it is from being negligent! With what wise foresight it manages so as to keep its provisions as long as possible! With its pincers it cuts the grains in half, for fear lest they should germinate and not serve for its food.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:62
verses.text: If they are damp it dries them; and it does not spread them out in all weathers, but when it feels that the air will keep of a mild temperature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:63
verses.text: Be sure that you will never see rain fall from the clouds so long as the ant has left the grain out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:64
verses.text: What language can attain to the marvels of the Creator? What ear could understand them? And what time would be sufficient to relate them? Let us say, then, with the prophet, "O Lord, how manifold are thy works! in wisdom hast thou made them all".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:65
verses.text: We shall not be able to say in self-justification, that we have learnt useful knowledge in books, since the untaught law of nature makes us choose that which is advantageous to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:66
verses.text: Do you know what good you ought to do your neighbour? The good that you expect from him yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:67
verses.text: Do you know what is evil? That which you would not wish another to do to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:68
verses.text: Neither botanical researches nor the experience of simples have made animals discover those which are useful to them; but each knows naturally what is salutary and marvellously appropriates what suits its nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:70
verses.text: Virtues exist in us also by nature, and the soul has affinity with them not by education, but by nature herself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:71
verses.text: We do not need lessons to hate illness, but by ourselves we repel what afflicts us, the soul has no need of a master to teach us to avoid vice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:72
verses.text: Now all vice is a sickness of the soul as virtue is its health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:73
verses.text: Thus those have defined health well who have called it a regularity in the discharge of natural functions; a definition that can be applied without fear to the good condition of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:74
verses.text: Thus, without having need of lessons, the soul can attain by herself to what is fit and conformable to nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:75
verses.text: Hence it comes that temperance everywhere is praised, justice is in honour, courage admired, and prudence the object of all aims; virtues which concern the soul more than health concerns the body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:76
verses.text: Children love your parents, and you, "parents provoke not your children to wrath".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:77
verses.text: Does not nature say the same? Paul teaches us nothing new; he only tightens the links of nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:78
verses.text: If the lioness loves her cubs, if the she wolf fights to defend her little ones, what shall man say who is unfaithful to the precept and violates nature herself; or the son who insults the old age of his father; or the father whose second marriage has made him forget his first children?  With animals invincible affection unites parents with children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:79
verses.text: It is the Creator, God Himself, who substitutes the strength of feeling for reason in them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:80
verses.text: From whence it comes that a lamb as it bounds from the fold, in the midst of a thousand sheep recognises the colour and the voice of its mother, runs to her, and seeks its own sources of milk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:81
verses.text: If its mother's udders are dry, it is content, and, without stopping, passes by more abundant ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:82
verses.text: And how does the mother recognise it among the many lambs? All have the same voice, the same colour, the same smell, as far at least as regards our sense of smell.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:83
verses.text: Yet there is in these animals a more subtle sense than our perception which makes them recognise their own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:84
verses.text: The little dog has as yet no teeth, nevertheless he defends himself with his mouth against any one who teases him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:85
verses.text: The calf has as yet no horns, nevertheless he already knows where his weapons will grow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:86
verses.text: Here we have evident proof that the instinct of animals is innate, and that in all beings there is nothing disorderly, nothing unforeseen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:87
verses.text: All bear the marks of the wisdom of the Creator, and show that they have come to life with the means of assuring their preservation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:88
verses.text: The dog is not gifted with a share of reason; but with him instinct has the power of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:89
verses.text: The dog has learnt by nature the secret of elaborate inferences, which sages of the world, after long years of study, have hardly been able to disentangle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:90
verses.text: When the dog is on the track of game, if he sees it divide in different directions, he examines these different paths, and speech alone fails him to announce his reasoning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:91
verses.text: The creature, he says, is gone here or there or in another direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:92
verses.text: It is neither here nor there; it is therefore in the third direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:93
verses.text: And thus, neglecting the false tracks, he discovers the true one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:94
verses.text: What more is done by those who, gravely occupied in demonstrating theories, trace lines upon the dust and reject two propositions to show that the third is the true one?  Does not the gratitude of the dog shame all who are ungrateful to their benefactors? Many are said to have fallen dead by their murdered masters in lonely places.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:95
verses.text: Others, when a crime has just been committed, have led those who were searching for the murderers, and have caused the criminals to be brought to justice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:96
verses.text: What will those say who, not content with not loving the Master who has created them and nourished them, have for their friends men whose mouth attacks the Lord, sitting at the same table with them, and, whilst partaking of their food, blaspheme Him who has given it to them?  5.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:97
verses.text: But let us return to the spectacle of creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:98
verses.text: The easiest animals to catch are the most productive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:99
verses.text: It is on account of this that hares and wild goats produce many little ones, and that wild sheep have twins, for fear lest these species should disappear, consumed by carnivorous animals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:100
verses.text: Beasts of prey, on the contrary, produce only a few and a lioness with difficulty gives birth to one lion; because, if they say truly, the cub issues from its mother by tearing her with its claws; and vipers are only born by gnawing through the womb, inflicting a proper punishment on their mother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:101
verses.text: Thus in nature all has been foreseen, all is the object of continual care.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:102
verses.text: If you examine the members even of animals, you will find that the Creator has given them nothing superfluous, that He has omitted nothing that is necessary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:103
verses.text: To carnivorous animals He has given pointed teeth which their nature requires for their support.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:104
verses.text: Those that are only half furnished with teeth have received several distinct receptacles for their food.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:105
verses.text: As it is not broken up enough in the first, they are gifted with the power of returning it after it has been swallowed, and it does not assimilate until it has been crushed by rumination.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:106
verses.text: The first, second, third, and fourth stomachs of ruminating animals do not remain idle; each one of them fulfils a necessary function.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:107
verses.text: The neck of the camel is long so that it may lower it to its feet and reach the grass on which it feeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:108
verses.text: Bears, lions, tigers, all animals of this sort, have short necks buried in their shoulders; it is because they do not live upon grass and have no need to bend down to the earth; they are carnivorous and eat the animals upon whom they prey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:109
verses.text: Why has the elephant a trunk? This enormous creature, the greatest of terrestrial animals, created for the terror of those who meet it, is naturally huge and fleshy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:110
verses.text: If its neck was large and in proportion to its feet it would be difficult to direct, and would be of such an excessive weight that it would make it lean towards the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:111
verses.text: As it is, its head is attached to the spine of the back by short vertebrae and it has its trunk to take the place of a neck, and with it it picks up its food and draws up its drink.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:112
verses.text: Its feet, without joints, like united columns, support the weight of its body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:113
verses.text: If it were supported on lax and flexible legs, its joints would constantly give way, equally incapable of supporting its weight, should it wish either to kneel or rise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:114
verses.text: But it has under the foot a little ankle joint which takes the place of the leg and knee joints whose mobility would never have resisted this enormous and swaying mass.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:115
verses.text: Thus it had need of this nose which nearly touches its feet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:116
verses.text: Have you seen them in war marching at the head of the phalanx, like living towers, or breaking the enemies' battalions like mountains of flesh with their irresistible charge? If their lower parts were not in accordance with their size they would never have been able to hold their own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:117
verses.text: Now we are told that the elephant lives three hundred years and more, another reason for him to have solid and unjointed feet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:118
verses.text: But, as we have said, his trunk, which has the form and the flexibility of a serpent, takes its food from the earth and raises it up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:119
verses.text: Thus we are right in saying that it is impossible to find anything superfluous or wanting in creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:120
verses.text: Well! God has subdued this monstrous animal to us to such a point that he understands the lessons and endures the blows we give him; a manifest proof that the Creator has submitted all to our rule, because we have been made in His image.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:121
verses.text: It is not in great animals only that we see unapproachable wisdom; no less wonders are seen in the smallest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:122
verses.text: The high tops of the mountains which, near to the clouds and continually beaten by the winds, keep up a perpetual winter, do not arouse more admiration in me than the hollow valleys, which escape the storms of lofty peaks and preserve a constant mild temperature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:123
verses.text: In the same way in the constitution of animals I am not more astonished at the size of the elephant, than at the mouse, who is feared by the elephant, or at the scorpion's delicate sting, which has been hollowed like a pipe by the supreme artificer to throw venom into the wounds it makes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:124
verses.text: And let nobody accuse the Creator of having produced venomous animals, destroyers and enemies of our life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:125
verses.text: Else let them consider it a crime in the schoolmaster when he disciplines the restlessness of youth by the use of the rod and whip to maintain order.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:127
verses.text: Beasts bear witness to the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:128
verses.text: Hast thou confidence in the Lord? "Thou shalt walk upon the asp and the basilisk and thou shalt trample under feet the lion and the dragon".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:129
verses.text: With faith thou hast the power to walk upon serpents and scorpions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:130
verses.text: Do you not see that the viper which attached itself to the hand of Paul, whilst he gathered sticks, did not injure him, because it found the saint full of faith? If you have not faith, do not fear beasts so much as your faithlessness, which renders you susceptible of all corruption.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:131
verses.text: But I see that for a long time you have been asking me for an account of the creation of man, and I think I can hear you all cry in your hearts, We are being taught the nature of our belongings, but we are ignorant of ourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:132
verses.text: Let me then speak of it, since it is necessary, and let me put an end to my hesitation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:133
verses.text: In truth the most difficult of sciences is to know one's self.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:134
verses.text: Not only our eye, from which nothing outside us escapes, cannot see itself; but our mind, so piercing to discover the sins of others, is slow to recognise its own faults.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:135
verses.text: Thus my speech, after eagerly investigating what is external to myself, is slow and hesitating in exploring my own nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:136
verses.text: Yet the beholding of heaven and earth does not make us know God better than the attentive study of our being does; I am, says the Prophet, fearfully and wonderfully made; that is to say, in observing myself I have known Thy infinite wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:137
verses.text: And God said "Let us make man".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:138
verses.text: Does not the light of theology shine, in these words, as through windows; and does not the second Person show Himself in a mystical way, without yet manifesting Himself until the great day? Where is the Jew who resisted the truth and pretended that God was speaking to Himself? It is He who spoke, it is said, and it is He who made.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:139
verses.text: "Let there be light and there was light".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Homilies 9:140
